title: A history of events in the Cienega Watershed

events.title: Cretaceous events (geologic)
events.description: Cretaceous experiences warm climate, high sea levels, inland seas, mass extinction
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Moisture and temperatures similar to today create new economic opportunities
events.description: Agriculture increasingly possible in watershed in floodplains and some dry locations.
events.source: Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: Widespread farming communities and settled village lifestyle develop
events.description: Large pithouses, courtyards, ceramics, settled life; larger villages, some ballcourts occur
events.source: Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: Hohokam and protohistoric use Colossal Cave Mountain Park area
events.description: Artifacts indicate that the Hohokam use areas of what today is Colossal Cave Mountain Park as a seasonal village and hunting camp; they use Colossal Cave for shelter, storage, and as a shrine
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Climate drying; Hohokam adapt with longer settlement and intensive agriculture
events.description: Some large Hohokam sites, public structures; agriculture aided with check dams, terraces; long-occupied sites at I-10 and Cienega Creek; plus smaller farming sites
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.

events.title: Proto-historic Apache and Sobaipuri Native Americans living in the Cienega Watershed
events.description: Sobaipuri [O'odham] communities found at multiple locations including Colossal Cave Park area
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Dryland farming possible along floodplains, washes and with irrigation in Cienega Watershed
events.description: Proto-historic, post-Hohokam groups living in smaller communities with diverse economies
events.source: Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001. .

events.title: Sobaipuri [O'odham] occupy and utilize the Santa Rita Mountains and watershed
events.description: Researchers have investigated protohistoric sites dating to mid-1700s (likely Sobaipuri but possibly Apache or Tohono O'odham) a roasting pit, house rings of stone. Reported by Kino and Manje occupied Santa Cruz and San Pedro river valleys, maintained agriculture-based villages.
events.source: Huckell BB. Sobaipuri Sites in the Rosemont Area. In: Tagg MD, Ervin RG, Huckell BB eds. Miscellaneous Archaeological Studies in the ANAMAX-Rosemont Land Exchange Area, Archaeological Series No. 147, Vol. 4. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum, University of Arizona.; 1984. pp. 107–130

events.title: Apache utilize area
events.description: Apache were reported to be widespread in Southern Arizona but no specific remains are attributed as Apache camps in the Cienega Watershed.
events.source: Bronitsky G, Merritt JD . The Archaeology of Southeast Arizona: A Class I Cultural Resources Inventory . Phoenix, AZ: Bureau of Land Management; 1986

events.title: Temperatures and moisture vary as in today's watershed climate
events.source: Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001. .

events.title: Sobaipuri [O'odham] probably move west to avoid Apache expansion
events.description: Some groups may have dispersed east as well
events.source: Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000.

events.title: Cattle travel through AZ with Spanish conquistadors and missionaries
events.description: Fray Marcos de Niza in 1539 and Francisco Vasquez de Coronado in 1540-1542 brought livestock with them as they travelled through Southern Arizona. No livestock were believed to have survived to reproduce at this time.
events.source: Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20

events.title: Spanish contact with Apache or other native groups
events.description: Apache and Sobaipuri [O'odham] living in area of early Spanish incursions
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Apaches in Arizona first noted by Spanish recorders
events.description: Captain Juan Mateo Manje assigned to guard Padre Eusebio Kino as he travels through S AZ and Sonora; records first comment about presence of Apaches in Pinalenos mountains.
events.source: Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site. Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:74

events.title: Sumas, Jacomes, Janos Indians occupy Chiricahua Mountains
events.description: Sumas, Jacomes, Janos Indians occupy Chiricahua Mountains.
events.source: Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:75

events.title: Eusebio Kino explores Southern Arizona bringing new plants and livestock
events.description: Eusebio Francisco Kino, Jesuit priest, enters southern Arizona in 1691. He brings gifts of livestock and plants from Europe to Indian settlements and founds 3 missions (Tumacacori, Guevavi, and San Xavier del Bac) and many visitas over the next 2 decades. These gifts mark the initiation of the spread of exotic organisms into the region.
events.source:
Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.
Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000.

events.title: Spanish military resettle non-Apaches indians west of Apacheria
events.description: Only Apache tribes recognized as inhabiting Apacheria.
events.source: Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:9

events.title: Early Spanish mining in Santa Cruz River valley
events.description: Early Spanish mining in Santa Cruz River valley.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:31-32

events.title: Early Spanish ranches at Arivaca and Sopori
events.description: Arivaca and Soproni Spanish ranches abandoned after Pima Indian 1751 revolt.
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Pima Indian revolts
events.description: Pima Indians revolt, murdering priests, burning missions, reversing Spanish settlement trends.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:47-49

events.title: San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio established at headwaters of San Pedro River
events.description: Spanish presidio is designed to protect local citizens and peaceful Indians from Apache depredations. Location unhealthy, water bad, and lack of adequate farm land leads to starvation of inhabitants.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:50-51

events.title: Nueva Vizcaya declares war against Apaches
events.description: New Spain's northern province formally declares war against Apaches and begins establishing presidios in northern Sonora (southern Arizona).
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:40

events.title: Spanish forces move easternmost settlement of Sobaipuri [O'odham] from San Pedro to Sonoita
events.description: Guevavi and Tubac presidios abandoned because of Apache raiding.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:40,49-50

events.title: Tubac has the largest population in Southern Arizona, ~500
events.description: At the time that the Franciscans take over missionary responsibilities from the Jesuits, Tubac is the largest settlement in the region with over 200 Hispanics and close to 300 Indians living around the presidio.
events.source: Officer J . Hispanic Arizona: 1536-1856. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1989:47

events.title: Guevavi mission and Tubac presidio abandoned because of Apache raiding
events.description: Devastating attacks by Apaches begin in 1768 on settlements in Santa Cruz, Sonoita Valleys. Visita at Sonoita abandoned in 1770. Guevavi deserted in 1774 and Tubac in 1775. All flee to last presidio at Tucson.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:53

events.title: San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio transferred from San Pedro headwaters to Fairbank
events.description: Location of San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio is unhealthy due to bad climate, bad water and lack of farmland. Presidio moved north to site near Fairbank on San Pedro River in 1775 and renamed Santa Cruz de Terranate. Again poor choice of location leaves troops open to Apache attack. Presidio is moved again in 1780.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:51

events.title: Spanish garrison established in San Bernardino to fight Apaches
events.description: Garrison at Fronteras, Sonora, moves north in 1775 to site in San Bernardino Valley one mile south of border. Poor choice of location; area open to repeated Apache attack. Garrison retreats to Fronteras five years later.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:50

events.title: Tucson Presidio established
events.description: In deciding on the most effective locations for the northern Spanish defensive forts, Hugo O'Conor chooses to situate the northernmost in Tucson on August 20, 1775. The defensive fortifications of the presidio are not completed until December 1783.
events.source:
Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:53
Officer J . Hispanic Arizona: 1536-1856. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1989: 50, 58

events.title: Sobaipuri [O'odham] move to Tucson after 1776
events.description: Decimated by Apache raids and disease, eventually Sobaipuri move to Tucson after 1776 and become absorbed into O'odham groups
events.source: Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000.

events.title: Mining near Tubac
events.description: Mining near Tubac.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:43-44

events.title: Santa Cruz de Terrenate Presidio moves again to Las Nutrias
events.description: The Presidio location is deemed not defensible and moves again to Las Nutrias in the headwaters of the San Pedro River 5 miles from the original San Mateo de Terrenate.
events.source:
Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:52
Officer J . Hispanic Arizona: 1536-1856. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1989: 64, 67

events.title: Apache Peace policy initiated
events.description: Ends when military funding terminates and rations discontinued. Apaches return to old pattern of raiding.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:55-57

events.title: Stock raising in Southern Arizona becomes important enterprise
events.description: Stock (cattle, sheep, mules, horses) raising essential to support Spanish communities of settled Indians, miners, military garrisons, and missions.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:60-61

events.title: General Land Office established
events.description: The GLO oversees the surveying, platting, and sale of the public lands in the Western United States and administers the Homestead Act and the Preemption Act in disposal of public lands.
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Mexican miners work gold deposits at Guevavi
events.description: Guevavi gold mine is one of the earliest mines in southern Arizona. It is worked earlier under the Spanish mission and finally abandoned in 1849 when Apache raiding becomes intolerable.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:59

events.title: Mexican policies change; encourage increased violence against Apaches
events.description: The Mexican period brings a sharp drop in levels of national (centralized) political and economic activity on the northern frontier; weaker than Spanish national control. Local politics and economy become more important. The northern provinces become more isolated than under Spanish government. Mexican authorities lose control of the northern frontier. Mexicans resort to increased violence when dealing with Apaches. They eventually place bounties on Apaches and hire bounty hunters to bring in Apache scalps. Bounty hunters prey on peaceful rancherias, which are easy targets, more than on hostile Apaches. Some presidios, apparently, poison Apaches. Apaches generally become more hostile and retaliate more frequently against the Mexicans than they did against the Spanish. Revenge becomes an important driving force of hostilities. The frontier economy declines during these years. Military garrisons decrease in size. Civilian militias become more important, although largely ineffective. Economic support by the central government of the Apaches declines. Mexican communities frequently take hostages to use as advantage against the Apaches. Apaches do the same. Apaches frequently trade goods to one community that they take from another. Political confusion exists on the northern frontier. Mexicans become increasingly worried about a general Apache revolt.
events.source: Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:82

events.title: Nine land grants established in Southern Arizona
events.description: Nine land grants established in Southern Arizona.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:60-66

events.title: Mexican Independence recognized
events.description: After 11 years of conflict against Spanish rule, Mexico wins independence.

events.title: San Jose de Sonoita and San Rafael de la Zanja Land Grants established.
events.description: San Jose de Sonoita land grant in upper Sonoita river area and San Rafael de la Zanja Land Grant in Upper Santa Cruz River area both established.
events.source: Officer, J et al. The Pimeria Alta: Missions and More. Tucson, AZ: Southwest Mission Research Center; 1996:106-108

events.title: San Ignacio del Babocomari land grant approved
events.description: Ignacio Elias and sister Eulalia purchase San Ignacio del Babocomari lands. ~34,000 acres for 380 pesos.
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Mexican-American War
events.description: The Mexican-American War, also known as the Mexican War, the US–Mexico War, the Invasion of Mexico, the U.S. Intervention, or the United States War Against Mexico, is an armed conflict between the United States of America and the United Mexican States from 1846 to 1848 in the wake of the 1845 U.S. annexation of Texas, which Mexico considers part of its territory despite the 1836 Texas Revolution.

events.title: Mexican-American War ends in Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
events.description: Mexican-American War ends on 2/3/1848. Mexico agrees to cede most of area now in US Southwest, including Arizona lands north of Gila River. US agrees to pay Mexico $15M in damages.

events.title: Emory boundary survey includes Sonoita Plains
events.description: Emory boundary survey reports on wildlife in region. Crew gets lost in Sonoita Plains, confused by 3 rivers. Reports on marshes, bogs, wildlife

events.title: First surveys of fishes in Southern Arizona
events.description: First surveys for fishes associated with boundary surveys.
events.source:
Minckley, WL, Marsh PC. Inland Fishes of the Greater Southwest, Chronicle of a Vanishing Biota. Tucson, AZ:The University of Arizona Press; 2009
Girard C. Ichthyology of the Boundary. Washington DC: US Government Printing Office;\; 1859

events.title: Anglo Americans begin to arrive in Southern Arizona region
events.description: The California Gold Rush of 1848 stimulates a major movement of Anglo Americans and other nationalities westward across the United States. Many entrepreneurs during their crossing note the available natural resources of wildlife, timber and grasslands and return to Arizona when their gold fever abates.

events.title: Department of the Interior established
events.description: The General Land Office is transferred to the Department of the Interior (DOI). The DOI later houses most other land agencies (National Park Service, Soil Conservation Service, which became the National Resources Conservation Service, the Bureau of Land Management and the US Fish & Wildlife Service). The Forest Service remains with the Department of Agriculture
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Gadsden Purchase
events.description: The Gadsden Treaty is signed on December 30, 1853 and ratified by Congress on April 25, 1854. The US purchases from Mexico lands south of the Gila River for $10,000,000. 29,670 square miles including the Cienega Valley become part of Arizona and New Mexico. Anglo-American farmers, ranchers, and miners begin to occupy Sonoita Valley in 1856. This important addition of land creates the opportunity to develop a southern (ie less snow restrictions) railroad route. The Arizona portion of the Southern Pacific Railroad is built in 1880-1881.

events.title: US flag raised over Tucson
events.description: William Kirkland, one of the 1st Dragoon troops, raises the American flag over Tucson on February 20, 1856, during the peaceful transfer of sovereignty of the Gadsden Purchase lands from Mexico to the United States.
events.source:
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131
McClintock J. Arizona. Prehistoric, Aboriginal, Pioneer, Modern. . Chicago: SJ Clarke Publishing Co; 1916

events.title: Camp Moore established near Rio Rico AZ
events.description: Camp Moore is established at the abandoned presidio of Calabasas. The first US troops arrive in 1856 to take control of the area from departing Mexican troops after the Gadsden Purchase is ratified. It is the first American military encampment in southern Arizona.
events.source: Collins W et al . The United States Military in Arizona, 1846-1945. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona State Historic Preservation Office; 1993:86-87

events.title: James Pennington and family settle on Sonoita Creek.
events.description: James Pennington and his family settle on Sonoita Creek near Fort Buchanan. They raise money by cutting hay to sell to the military.
events.source: Farish TE. A History of Arizona, Volume 2. San Francisco, CA:Filmer Brothers Electrotype Company; 1915:199-200

events.title: Anglo Americans begin farming in Sonoita Creek area
events.description: Early settlers who were engaged in farming on the Sonoita Creek...included EG Pennington, Tom Gardner, William Kirkland, Tom Hughes, and John Cady who located in the order named between 1857 and 1872. These pioneers grew corn, beans, and wheat with the use of a occasional flood waters, after the example of the Pima and Papago Indians.'
events.source: McOmie AM. Dry farming in Arizona. Agricultural Experimental Station . Feb.1, 1918. Bulletin 84:537

events.title: Interstate stage lines operate across Southern Arizona
events.description: Numerous stage lines carry mail and passengers through southern Arizona. The San Antonio-San Diego Mail Line (also known as the Jackass Mail) operates in early 1857, and the Butterfield Stage Company from 1857 to early 1861 when Confederate separatists in Texas damage company resources. Butterfield builds a relay station in lower Cienega Creek (near present day Marsh Station).Three other stage lines restart transport in 1870 but close for good in 1881 when Southern Pacific RR completes its line across AZ. Many other stage lines continue to operate within AZ. One line runs from Pantano to Patagonia through the upper Cienega Valley.

events.title: Fort Buchanan established
events.description: Camp Moore abandoned and Fort Buchanan established 3 miles west of Sonoita. The Fort Buchanan location is a fever pit; all soldiers contract malaria. Buchanan abandoned and burned to the ground on 6/31/1861 when confederate soldiers threaten invasion.
events.source: Collins W et al . The United States Military in Arizona, 1846-1945. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona State Historic Preservation Office; 1993:90

events.title: Cochise and Chiricahua Apaches initiate 11-year conflict with Americans
events.description: Second Lieutenant George Bascom from Fort Buchanan confronts Chiricahua Apache chief Cochise at Apache Pass and falsely accuses him of abducting a young Mexican boy from a ranch near Sonoita. Both sides take prisoners, including relatives of Cochise, and kill them. Cochise begins a campaign to eliminate all settlers from Southeast Arizona that lasts until the establishment of the Chiricahua Apache reservation in 1872 in the Sulphur Springs Valley.
events.source: Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:88-90

events.title: Civil War in Southern Arizona
events.description: In 1861 the southern half of the New Mexico territory is claimed as part of the Confederate States, and a confederate garrison is established in Tucson. Tucson is 'liberated' by the 1st California Volunteer Cavalry on May 20, 1862. The major consequence for inhabitants of Southern Arizona is the withdrawal of most established military encampments leaving settlers to defend themselves against intensified Apache depredations. Most settlers abandon the area during the war.

events.title: The Homestead Act of 1862
events.description: Creates orderly system to transfer public lands to private individuals. Law originally offered 160 acres of surveyed land to a claimant who was or who had applied for citizenship after he/she had resided on and cultivated land for 5 years. The Arizona General Land Office was moved between Prescott, Tucson, Florence, and Phoenix.
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Confederate occupation of Tucson for 80 days
events.description: Captain Sherod Hunter and 25 men arrive in Tucson from Mesilla and claim town for the Confederacy. In response to advancing Confederate troops, Colonel James Carleton and 2000 California Volunteers march westward to defend the territory. They arrive in Tucson on May 20, 1862. Confederate troops abandon town and return to Mesilla.
events.source: Sonnichsen CL . Tucson Life and Times of an American City. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 1982

events.title: Fort Bowie established in Apache Pass
events.description: Fort Bowie established to protect water and transportation access in Apache Pass. Major player in control and management of Chiricahua Apache. Fort Bowie is abandoned on October 17, 1894.
events.source:
McChristian D. Fort Bowie, Arizona, Combat Post of the Southwest, 1858-1894. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2005
Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: President Lincoln creates Arizona Territory
events.description: Arizona is originally the western half of the New Mexico Territory, but inhabitants demand separation because of lack of support from the territorial capital in Mesilla. Argument that influences Congressional approval is that the area needs a closer official government to oversee the great silver wealth produced from mining operations.
events.source: Sonnichsen CL . Tucson Life and Times of an American City. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 1982

events.title: Fort Crittenden established near headwaters of Sonoita Creek
events.description: Fort Crittenden established ½ mile NE of old Fort Buchanan. New location is out of the marshy area and therefore a more healthy environment for soldiers. Purpose of establishment is to continue effort to control movement and activities of the Chiricahua Apache and to protect ranchers and miners in the Sonoita and Cienega Valleys.
events.source: McChristian D. Fort Bowie, Arizona, Combat Post of the Southwest, 1858-1894. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2005

events.title: First General Land Office opens in Prescott
events.description:
The General Land Office opens its first Arizona office in Prescott in 1870. It is open until
1904. In 1873 a second office is opened in Florence, moved to Tucson in 1881, and subsequently moved again to Phoenix in 1905.
events.source:
Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.
Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Apache raiding in Sonoita, AZ
events.description: Raiding in Sonoita leads to Camp Grant massacre, according to early Anglo settlers
events.source: Farish TE. A History of Arizona, Volume 2. San Francisco, CA:Filmer Brothers Electrotype Company; 1915:271-281

events.title: Ranching starts ecological changes in Southern Arizona
events.description: Prior to 1872, Southern Arizona is described as 'a wealth of plant growth practically everywhere'. Following the Civil War, large numbers of cattle are moved into Arizona. Cattlemen from more moderate climates in the east fail to recognize the potential problem from regularly occurring drought in the Sonoran Desert. They unknowingly overstock the ranges during an unusually wet period, and pay the price in the following inevitable droughts and floods.
events.source: Allen L.. Roots of the Arizona livestock industry. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):9-13

events.title: Cattle become dominant livestock in Southeasten Arizona
events.description: Beginning in late 1800s and continuing to today, cattle become dominant regional ecological force, an exotic influence on native ecosystems.
events.source:
Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131

events.title: Four room Empire Ranch House constructed
events.description: Flat-roofed, four-room house with central hallway (zaguan) constructed of hand-cast adobe blocks between 1871 and 1874 by William Wakefield.
events.source: Harrison LS. Heart of the Empire. Washington, DC: National Park Service; 1992.

events.title: Chiricahua Apache Reservation established, then cancelled
events.description: Chiricahua Apache Reservation established. First interlude of peace in more than 40 years. Boundaries include San Simon Valley south of Gila River to Mexico border and Dragoon Range to New Mexico border. Reservation cancelled in 1876. Land returned to public domain and Apaches removed to San Carlos reservation. Many renew raiding patterns.
events.source: Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Yellowstone National Park established
events.description: Yellowstone is the first reserved land to be formally set aside by Congress as a National Park. Congress, and later the executive branch, recognize the importance of protecting certain pieces of land from natural resource extraction and development and for preservation and recreation.

events.title: General Mining Law passed
events.description: The General Mining Act of 1872 identifies mineral lands subject to exploration, occupation, and purchase under stipulated conditions. The law governs prospecting and mining for gold, silver, copper and other valuable minerals. It codifies a system to acquiring and protecting claims. Any unpatented claim must be worked every year. Patent provision transfers lands to private ownership. Example: Rosemont copper mining site.
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Cattle boom in Southern Arizona
events.description: Large numbers of cattle are moved to Arizona following the Civil War from overgrazed ranches in Texas.
events.source: Sayre N.. The cattle boom in Southern Arizona: towards a critical political ecology. Journal of the Southwest. 1999. 41(2):239-271

events.title: Fort Lowell moves out of Tucson
events.description: General Crook orders Fort Lowell to be moved from downtown Tucson to northeastern corner of Tucson basin. The shift in location brings the military encampment closer to center of Chiricahua Apache operations. The post is closed in 1891.
events.source: Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: San Xavier Reservation established
events.description: Initial small reservation granted by Ulysses S. Grant in 1874. Expanded Tohono O'odham Reservation lands further west added in 1917.

events.title: Township around Empire Ranch surveyed
events.description: Land open to homesteading claims.
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Southern Pacific Mail Line operates a stagecoach station at La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: Southern Pacific Mail Line operates a stagecoach stop at La Posta Quemada Ranch on what today is part of Colossal Cave Mountain Park. According to Edward Vail, there is a burned stage station here by 1875, 'hence the name Posta Quemada--'Burnt Station' '.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Walter Vail and Herbert Hislop purchase Empire Ranch
events.description: William Wakefield sells 160-acre homestead to Edward Nye Fish and Simon Silverberg; Walter Vail, Herbert Hislop (and later John Harvey) purchase Fish's 160-acre Empire Ranch for $2,000.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Ed Schieffelin discovers silver ore at Tombstone
events.description: Ed Schieffelin makes first discovery of silver ore at Tombstone. Initiates explosion of mineral exploration throughout southern Arizona.
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Fort Huachuca established
events.description: Fort Huachuca established in 1877 as one of the military encampments to aid in control of and prevention of depredations by the Chiricahua Apaches after their reservation had been terminated. The fort's establishment coincides with some of the worst conflicts with a small group of Apaches who refuse to stay at the San Carlos reservation and instead escape to follow Naiche and Geronimo. The site is chosen to have quick access to the border region.
events.source:
Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.
Collins W et al . The United States Military in Arizona, 1846-1945. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona State Historic Preservation Office; 1993:30

events.title: Empire Ranch House rear addition rooms constructed
events.description: Eleven rooms are added to the original four-room Empire Ranch house to provide space for offices and staff.
events.source: The Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2015

events.title: Good rain year
events.source: Woolley JJ, Wilkening L. The Empire Ranch and Walter L. Vail. The Copper State Journal. 2002. 37(4):12-17:14

events.title: National Mail and Transportation Company takes over from Southern Pacific Mail Line
events.description: National Mail and Transportation Company takes over from the Southern Pacific Mail Line; both these lines use the stage stop at Mountain Springs Ranch (today La Posta Quemada Ranch in Colossal Cave Mountain Park).
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Solomon Lick builds the Mountain Springs Hotel and Stage Station
events.description: Lick builds hotel about a mile west of 'Posta Quemada' or 'Burnt Station' location noted by Edward Vail. La Posta Quemada Ranch's Mountain Springs Grove is located here today.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Empire Ranch partner, Herbert Hislop, leaves partnership
events.description: Herbert Hislop, Walter Vail's original ranching partner, leaves partnership due to a combination of family difficulties in England and exhaustion with ranching challenges. Hislop sells his share to Vail for $7,000 and departs for England.
events.source: An Englishman's Arizona. The Ranching Letters of Herbert R.Hislop 1876-1878. Tucson, AZ: The Overland Press; 1965

events.title: Rosemont Mining claims located in Wash and Barrel Canyons
events.description: William McCleary and L.J. Rose begin locating Rosemont mining claims near Wasp and Barrel Canyon. Rosemont claims in present day Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont Narragansett claim located
events.description: Rosemont Narragansett claim: James K. Brown locates the claim and begins intermittent operations.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: John T. Dillon finds the mineral deposits that become the Total Wreck mine
events.description: Total Wreck silver ore mostly found in surface deposits.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:29

events.title: Colossal Cave discovered by Solomon Lick
events.description: Searching for stray cows, Lick discovers an entrance to 'either a very extensive old mine, or a wonderful cave,' and undertakes a series of explorations of what today is known as Colossal Cave.

events.title: Pantano becomes major cattle shipping point
events.description: Southern Pacific Railroad reaches Pantano. Pantano Station becomes the primary cattle shipping point for the Empire Ranch.and others.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Empire Ranch House Victorian Addition constructed
events.description: A separate three-room home (Victorian Addition) is constructed at the Empire Ranch by John Harvey for his wife.
events.source: Harrison LS. Heart of the Empire. Washington, DC: National Park Service; 1992

events.title: Cienega Valley supports 6,000 cattle, 23,000 sheep
events.description: Empire (Vails) and Cienega (Sanford) Ranches, the two largest stockraising operations, graze over 5,000 cattle and 23,000 sheep.. A number of other smaller ranches and homesteads in the valley are also running cattle and sheep.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:41

events.title: Sonoita and Babocomari thick with Sacaton and Saltgrass
events.description: Sonoita area and Babocomari Land Grant are thick with Sacaton and Saltgrass.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:42

events.title: Availability of water affects use of grasslands
events.description: Control of grasslands was determined by availability and control of water.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad completed through Arizona; opens new markets, closes others
events.description:
Completion of SPRR through Arizona opens new national markets to SE AZ ranchers, new shipping opportunities for miners. 
On the other hand, although local stage lines remain in operation, some into the 1930s, this immediately elimintes most interstate lines, including National Mail and Transportation Company. Stagecoach stations, including Mountain Springs on La Posta Quemda Ranch, are no longer needed.
events.source:
Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:19-61
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:44
Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Multiple rain events cause significant flooding damage and erosion in washes and riverbeds
events.description: Droughts and floods accompanied by severe overgrazing are major causes of arroyo formation, water channel deepening, and decline of water table throughout SE AZ

events.title: Severe drought decimates forage
events.description: Up to 75% of cattle die after nearly all forage has been decimated; ecosystem has not co-evolved with this type of grazing intensity
events.source: Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Vail's Siding facilitates trains moving east and west
events.description: Vail's Siding is built on the last stretch of land before the railroad tracks enter Cienega Creek. A siding is a track that branches out from the main line so that trains can pass each other safely.
events.source: Lamb JJ, Pinto RL. Voices of Vail The Town Between the Tracks [Timeline]. Vail, AZ: Vail Preservation Society; 2009

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad tracks make it to Punta de Agua
events.description: By April 1880, Southern Pacific Railroad tracks make it to Punta de Agua where the Pantano Wash and Cienega Creek meet along the old wagon road. Railroad is constructed as a levee in the broad floodplain of Cienega.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Edward L. Vail becomes an Empire Ranch partner
events.description: Edward (Ned) L. Vail, Walter Vail's brother, becomes a partner in the Empire Ranch
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Empire Mining and Development Co operate Total Wreck mine and milling operations
events.description: Major development of Total Wreck mine and milling operations by Empire Mining and Development Co. Mine produces $500,000 of silver ore that supports expansion of cattle and land operations at Empire Ranch. Silver market declines dramatically in 1884.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:48-49

events.title: Walter Vail files on mining and mill sites to acquire water
events.description: Walter Vail files on numerous mining and mill sites primarily to acquire and secure water sources.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:58

events.title: International Boundary and Water Commission formed
events.description: Commission surveys the international boundary from El Paso TX to San Diego CA finishing in 1889. Still functioning but changed over time in its authorities, the IBWC deals with issues along the US-Mexico border, especially related to water sources, amounts, quality, and with boundary issues

events.title: Empire Ranch partner, John Harvey, marries
events.description: John Harvey marries Alice Maud Annan in England in April and brings her to the Empire Ranch. In August Harvey sells his house at the Empire to Margaret Vail and leaves the partnership.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:56

events.title: Empire Ranch partner, Walter Vail, marries
events.description: Walter Vail marries Margaret Newhall in New Jersey and brings her to live at the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Total Wreck silver mine in operation
events.description: The Total Wreck silver mine operates in the Empirita Mountains producing over $500,000 in revenue for the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Walter Vail acquires Happy Valley (Rincon Mountains) and Meadow Valley Ranches (Cienega Valley)
events.description: Walter Vail acquires the Happy Valley ranch in eastern Rincon Mountains and Don Sanford’s Meadow Valley ranch at northern end of Cienega Valley. Acquisition of Meadow Valley ranch provides water source to run Total Wreck mine milling operations. Both provide major control of grasslands in region.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:58

events.title: VR Ranch established in Rosemont Valley
events.description: Edward Vail and Risley establish VR Ranch, associated with the Vails’ Empire Ranch. Located in present day Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Empire Land & Cattle Company established
events.description: Empire Land & Cattle Co. created with Walter Vail, principal shareholder.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Hidden Valley or Scholefield Ranch established
events.description: George Scholefield founds the Hidden Valley or Scholefield Ranch. Located in present Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Walter Vail expands stockraising business into breeding race horses
events.description: Walter Vail, like many other large cattle operators, expands stock-raising business into breeding race horses.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:67

events.title: Walter Vail and Josiah Vosburg operate Pantano Ranch on Cienega Creek
events.description: Walter Vail partners with Josiah Vosburg to operate 2700 acre Pantano ranch on Cienega Creek
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Summer drought
events.description: A summer drought and heavy mortality for cattle leads to reduction in stock by ranchers for the next season.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:45

events.title: Final surrender and deportation of Chiricahua Apache
events.description: Final surrender and deportation of Chiricahua Apache to San Augustine prison in Florida. Southeastern Arizona now released from development restrictions.
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Flash flooding
events.description: Flash flooding on record in July.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:76

events.title: Vails sell Total Wreck mine
events.description: Vails sell Total Wreck mine.
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Hatch Act
events.description: The Hatch Act, signed into law by President Lincoln, provides funds to state colleges (University of Arizona) to create agricultural experiment stations to do research on farming systems and to share that knowledge with ranchers and farmers.

events.title: Three men, accused of a killing, hide out in Colossal Cave
events.description: Three gamblers, Gibson, Murphy, and Moyer, feuding with another gambler named Levy, call Levy out of the Cosmopolitan Saloon in Tucson and each takes a shot at him. Levy is killed, and Gibson, Murphy, and Moyer escape into the Rincon Mountains and hide in Colossal Cave. They then move on to the Catalinas, then the Galiuros. They are captured and put in Pima County jail, where they are reported to have tricked and overpowered their jailer, George Cooler, leaving him tied up and gagged in their cell. They set six other prisoners free, and all escape. Within a month of the jailbreak, George Cooler pleads guilty to letting the prisoners go. Ultimately, Gibson, Murphy, and Moyer are recaptured and brought to trial on murder charges. Murphy and Moyer are found guilty—but Gibson is acquitted on the grounds that Levy was already dead when Gibson’s bullet hit him.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Three train robberies on the Southern Pacific line by the same gang
events.description:
April 27, 1887: Three masked men ambush westbound Southern Pacific Express Train Number 20 near Vail, Arizona. They bring it to a halt by setting off explosives on the tracks, signaling with a red train lantern, and shooting the cars full of holes. Wells, Fargo Express Messenger Charles F. Smith barricades himself and the safe behind the locked door of the express car. The bandits force the engineer to carry a heavy explosive back to the express car and tell Smith to open the safe and get out or they will both be blown to kingdom come. Smith complies, and the robbers get away with about $3,000 in currency. 
August 10, 1887: Two of the robbers from the April holdup rob Train Number 20 again, between Pantano and Vail, this time making off with a considerable quantity of gold and Mexican silver dollars. 
August 16, 1887: Two caves are 'discovered' about 12 miles from Pantano by the posses scouring the area for the train robbers, who have escaped. Both caves are thought to have been used by the outlaws. Today, one, 'Five Mile Cave at Mountain Springs,' is Colossal Cave, and the other is probably a small shelter cave elsewhere in Colossal Cave Mountain Park. The bandits are thought to have rested at Mountain Springs [La Posta Quemada] Ranch and all the tracking parties use it as their headquarters.
October 17, 1887: Two men attempt to rob a train about four miles east of El Paso, Texas. They are the same robbers; this time they are shot down by Wells Fargo Messenger J. Ernest Smith. The third bandit, who has been involved only in the first robbery, is apprehended and sentenced to serve five years in the Territorial Penitentiary in Yuma.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Largest known earthquake in Arizona
events.description:
May 3, 1887: Largest known earthquake in Arizona, estimated seismic level on Richter Scale between 7.2 and 7.4. It is centered in Batopito, Sonora, Mexico; just a few miles away in Bavispe, Sonora, adobe buildings are in ruins, and 40 people are killed. In Arizona, breaks up playas, forms Mustang Mountains skyline later used in Red River film. Event changes underground water flows and creates many springs. Initiates major fires in all Southeast Arizona mountain ranges from falling rocks. Chimneys at Empire Ranch collapse. It is reported from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, to Phoenix, and from Yuma to Santa Fe, New Mexico. 
May 30, 1887: Tombstone reports significant aftershock. Other significant aftershocks occur August 27, 1887, and November 11, 1887, which is the second aftershock in two weeks, and cracks wooden depot buildings in Pantano.
events.source: McGarvin, TA. The 1887 Sonoran Earthquake: It Wasn't Our Fault . Arizona Bureau of Geology and Mineral Technology Field Notes. Summer 1987. Vol 17, No 2

events.title: Major floods in Cienega Creek require moving Southern Pacific railroad tracks
events.description: Major floods through lower Cienega Creek stimulate Southern Pacific RR to move tracks out of floodplain to higher ground from just east of Vail to Pantano.
events.source: David Myrick. Railroads of Arizona. Volume 1. The Southern Roads. Berkeley, CA: Howell North Books; 1975. 115

events.title: Heavy winter rainfall during winter
events.description: Winter rainfall causes over-optimism for future grass availability among cattle ranchers
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:53

events.title: Martinez and Lopez families known to have ranched in the area
events.description: Martinez and Lopez families ranching in the area; homesteads never patented. Within present day Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Beavers gone from Cienega Creek
events.description: Beavers lost from Gila River System including Cienega Creek

events.title: Greaterville gold deposits depleted at Kentucky Camp
events.description: Greaterville gold deposits ''worked-out' with traditional panning techniques at Kentucky Camp
events.source: Doumas, M. Kentucky Camp Interpretive Plan. Personal communication.May 10, 2013.

events.title: Solomon Lick sells Mountain Springs Ranch
events.description: Lick sells to 'William Shaw & John Craps' and Mary Anna Shaw; Shaw operates the ranch through 1918
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Empire Ranch cattle driven to California
events.description: Edward 'Ned' Vail and Empire Ranch foreman Tom Turner drive cattle overland to Warner's Ranch, CA to evade Southern Pacific RR rate increase.
events.source:
Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978
Vail, Edward L. Diary of a Desert Trail: 1880 Cattle Drive from Arizona to California. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2016

events.title: Forest Reserve Act of 1891
events.description: Congress gives the President the authority to set aside reservations of land to protect timber and water resources. The act provides no guidance or financial support for administration or management of those reserves.

events.title: Major drought decimates cattle industry in Southeastern Arizona
events.description: Two-year long drought causes 50-75% loss of livestock as forage severely depleted and springs and wells dry up.
events.source:
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:53
Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: William McCleary becomes first Postmaster of Rosemont Post Office
events.description: William McCleary, part time rancher and miner, has been exploring the Santa Rita Mountains looking for copper since 1874.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: McCleary and Rose incorporate the Rosemont Smelting and Mining Co.
events.description: Rosemont: William McCleary and J.L. Rose incorporate the Rosemont Smelting and Mining Co. in present day Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont Copper Company begins
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Empire Land & Cattle Company headquarters moved to Los Angeles
events.description: Walter Vail moves the headquarters of the Empire Land & Cattle Company and his family from the Empire Ranch to Los Angeles, CA. Empire Ranch left under the management of foreman Hadden McFadden.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Heavy summer rains
events.description: Tremendous summer rains, high cattle production, coupled with high cattle prices causes ranching over-optimism. Ranchers hold cattle on ranges hoping for even higher prices.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:54

events.title: Forest Reserve Organic Act
events.description: The act specifies the purpose for which forest reserves can be established and gives the Forest Service the authority to manage forest lands in order to protect water resources or control access to timber resources. The act allows holders of patented lands or valid homestead claims within forest boundaries to trade acreage for other unclaimed lands from the public domain. Presently the law must to be applied in conjunction with MUSYA and NFMA.
events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.
events.source (original): Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.title: Cienega School District No. 36 established [see line 170]
events.description: Pima County Board of Supervisors establishes District No. 36 when petitioned by citizens of Cienega Valley. District HQ is located at Crane & Fraker's Ranch.
events.source: Lamb JJ. Voices of Vail School Timeline. Vail, AZ: Vail Preservation Society; 2016

events.title: Drought
events.description: Despite losses of animals, high cattle prices keep ranchers from financial loss.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55

events.title: Lewisohn Brothers patent 21 mining and 7 mill claims in Rosemont area
events.description: Rosemont employes about 100 men
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Walter Vail and Carroll Gates buy 1,000 acres from Sierra Forest reserve lands
events.description: Vail and partner Carroll Gates buy ~1000 (and most likely much more than that) acres of scrip from lands in the Sierra Forest Reserve. In 1899 they exchange scrip for over 2000 acres of lands in Empire Valley and other southern valleys. These sites cover many water sources.
events.source:
Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.
Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Spanish-American War
Freight road built from Helvetia to Vail's Station
events.description: This road is needed to transport ore from the mines in and around Helvetia to a point where it can be shipped for processing. Helvetia Mining Company approaches the Pima County Board of Supervisors about sharing the cost of the road and bringing the business to Tucson. Inaction on the part of the Supervisors brings the road to Vail's Siding. Mining in the Santa Rita Mountains and the new road are catalysts for growth in the area.
events.source: Lamb JJ. The Old Vail Post Office, Connecting the Greater Vail Community Since 1908. The Smoke Signal. The Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2011. 90

events.title: Samuel J. Holsinger surveys Santa Catalina Mountain for future Forest Reserve
events.description: Samuel J. Holsinger surveys Santa Catalina Mountain area for a future Forest Reserve.
events.source: Klein JB. Preserving Our Western Natural and Historical Heritage: the Enduring Legacy of SJ Holsinger. The Smoke Signal, Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2008. 84:77-136

events.title: Land degradation in Southern Arizona
events.description: The severe drought of 1891-1894 that causes rapid ecological decline at the beginning of the 20th century is well documented. Protective vegetation has died along the streambanks and in the desert valleys, many cattle die from starvation. The decline of cattle numbers continues until 1900, when 'range and watershed conditions throughout most of Arizona south of Gila River were at an all time low point'. Overgrazing is identified as the major cause of land degradation, among other factors such as road construction, mining, and cultivation.
events.source:
Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20
Thornber J. J.. The Grazing Ranges of Arizona . College of Agriculture, University of Arizona (Tucson, AZ); Sep. 21,1910

events.title: Pancho Villa visits Bill Williams at Benson
events.description: Circle Bar Ranch's Bill Williams is friends with Pancho Villa; Ida Williams, born c. 1900, has her picture taken sitting in Pancho Villa's lap at age 3 while he visits Benson

events.title: Tohono O'Odham move from Greaterville to San Xavier
events.description: While some Tohono O'Odham have already left the Greaterville area, once the Tohono O'Odham Reservation is established in 1916, further movement occurs. Part of the Tohono O'Odham Nation, the San Xavier reservation is first established in 1874.
events.source: Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Rangelands severely denuded
events.description: Botanists and ranchers concerned about future of grasslands and cattle industry
events.source:
Thornber J. J.. The Grazing Ranges of Arizona . College of Agriculture, University of Arizona (Tucson, AZ); Sep. 21,1910
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131

events.title: Generally dry conditions; heavy summer rains
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:120

events.title: Overgrazing degraded quality of Southern Arizona grasslands
events.description: David Griffiths, a botanist with the Arizona Agricultural Experiment, sends a survey to cattlemen in the area in order to document how excessive and continued grazing over time has degraded the quality of the ranges of Southern AZ
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:44

events.title: Drought period; heavy calf drop
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55

events.title: Santa Rita Mountain region surveyed for future forest reserve
events.description: Santa Rita Mountain region surveyed by Albert Potter and Royal Kellogg for future forest reserve.
events.source: Kellogg R. Forest Conditions in Southern Arizona. Forest and Irrigation. 1992. 8:501-505

events.title: First federal land survey establishes boundaries of San Ignacio del Babocomari Grant
events.description: The first federal land survey in the Audubon Research Ranch (Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society) area in June 1902, establishes boundaries of San Ignacio del Babocomari Grant.
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: James Stetson acquires Kentucky Camp mining claims, water rights
events.description: Stetson acquires mining claims, water rights and reservoirs for a large-scale hydraulic gold mining operation. George McAneny and James Stetson form the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company on October 3rd.
events.source: Orell FL. Kentucky Camp and the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company. Kentucky Camp Chronicle [Newsletter]. 1998. February

events.title: Santa Rita Forest Reserve proclaimed
events.description: Santa Rita is the first forest reserve to be established in southern Arizona and is set aside primarily because of its grass resources rather than its timber.
events.source:
Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.
Pinto RL. Cattle Grazing in the National Parks: Historical Development and History of Management in Three Southern Arizona Parks [dissertation]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 2014

events.title: Santa Catalina Forest Reserve established
events.description: Santa Catalina Forest Reserve is proclaimed by Theodore Roosevelt to protect water sources and to create summer recreation sites for residents of Tucson. The Rincon Mountains are added to the Santa Catalina Reserve in 1907.
events.source:
Sayre N. Recognizing History in Range Ecology: 100 Years of Science and Management. In: McClaran MP et al eds. Santa Rita Experimental Range: 100 Years (1903 to 2003). Ogden, UT:US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station; 2003. p.1-15
Klein JB. Preserving Our Western Natural and Historical Heritage: the Enduring Legacy of SJ Holsinger. The Smoke Signal, Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2008. 84:77-136

events.title: Good season for rainfall, forage, and a heavy calf drop
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55

events.title: Vail School District No. 20 established
events.description: Vail School District No. 20 established by Pima County Board of Supervisors after a petition by Vail residents. District contains Township 16 South, Range 16 East.
events.source: Lamb JJ. Voices of Vail School Timeline. Vail, AZ: Vail Preservation Society; 2016

events.title: Dry winter
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131.

events.title: US Immigration Service established to prevent illegal crossings
events.description: US Immigration Service established to prevent illegal crossings of both humans and livestock.
events.source: Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: F.M. Chamberlain surveys fish distribution and species in Southern Arizona
events.description: F.M. Chamberlain surveys fish in southern Arizona; records fish distribution and species descriptions in the Santa Cruz River basin
events.source: Minckley WL. Frederick Morton Chamberlain's 1904 Survey of Arizona Fishes, with Annotations. Journal of the Southwest . 1999. 41(2)177-238
events.source (original): Chamberlain FM. Notes on Work in Arizona. Unpublished manuscript in the file of the US Bureau of Fisheries, Department of Commerce and Labor, National Archives.

events.title: First Ranger cabin built at Old Rosemont
events.description: Cabin built at Old Rosemont is used by Forest Supervisor Thomas Meagher and Ranger Armour Scholefield.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Cattle overgrazing the Santa Rita Forest
events.description: Range management on the Santa Rita Forest Reserve (later the Coronado National Forest) begins with an emphasis on reducing the stocking rates. Managers institute a policy of 'transfer reductions' requiring a 10% reduction in permitted numbers each time a permit is transferred to a new permittee. Despite its good intentions, the policy is not effective in reducing overgrazing; the resulting damage on the range is due to the lack of control over cattle movement, to unpermitted cattle trespass, and to the lack of accurate data on the actual number of livestock on the range.
events.source: Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20

events.title: Tunnel excavated into Colossal Cave
events.description: Otto Schley, businessman and Vail Postmaster, drives a 75-ft tunnel into Colossal Cave in order to mine bat guano, takes out seven train carloads before the resource is exhausted. Tunnel serves today as ingress and egress for bat species using Colossal Cave

events.title: Chinese workers move Southern Pacific line out of Cienega Creek; Pantano moves about a mile
events.description: Over 1,000 Chinese railroad workers move the Southern Pacific Railroad main line out of Cienega Creek due to frequent flooding and track washouts occurring annually. 14 tons of powder are used to speed up the realignment. An outbreak of smallpox slows the work and at least one worker dies. The town of Pantano is moved about one mile north to the new rail line.
events.source: David Myrick. Railroads of Arizona. Volume 1. The Southern Roads. Berkeley, CA: Howell North Books; 1975:115

events.title: Wild ducks fill the lagoons along Cienega Creek
events.description: The Arizona Daily star reports that hunters are drawn by lagoons full of wild ducks along the Cienega.
events.source: Duck Killers at Vails. Arizona Daily Star. March 3, 1894.

events.title: Cienaga [sic] School District No. 36 established [duplicated with some differences in line 141]; they should be combined
events.description: Commencing at a point two miles north of the residence of Crane and Fraker in Section 10, Township 16S, Ranch 16E.
events.source: Lamb JJ. Voices of Vail School Timeline. Vail, AZ: Vail Preservation Society; 2016

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad builds a cistern at Vail
events.description: Cienega Creek/Pantano is just about a mile to the northeast, but water is not easily available at the Vail siding. A well is not established at the Vail town site until 1992.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. The 1908 Old Vail Post Office. Smokesignal. Corral of the Westerners; 2011. 1-32:31

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad builds a depot at Vail
events.description: So many people are flagging down the train at Vail's siding that the Southern Pacific Railroad decides to build a depot. The depot also includes Class IV postal service.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. The 1908 Old Vail Post Office. Smokesignal. Corral of the Westerners; 2011. 1-32:9

events.title: Frogs shipped daily from Vail
events.description: Frogs captured from Cienega Creek are shipped daily from the Cienega Ranch (Rancho del Lago in 2017) aboard the Sunset Express to the Adams & Co. grocery store in Tucson.
events.source: Lamb JJ, Pinto RL. Voices of Vail The Town Between the Tracks [Timeline]. Vail, AZ: Vail Preservation Society; 2009

events.title: Rancho del Lago sold to Cleaveland Putnam by Alma Monthan Tattersfield
events.description: Putnam removes the orchards, farm fields, and large trees. They are replaced with a large ranch house, castle-themed guest casitas, gate house, swimming pool, airstrip, stable, and half-mile horse track.
events.source: Monthan, George. Vail, the Tattersfield/Monthan Family. Personal communication.2009.

events.title: Water use agreement between Cleaveland Putnam and Mattie Adkins
events.description: Legal agreement reached between Cleaveland and Margaret Putnam and Mattie Adkins to divert water from the irrigation canal carrying water from Cienega Creek to Rancho del Lago. On Sundays between noon and 6:00 p.m., water is diverted to irrigate Mattie Adkins crops.

events.title: Pantano Post Office closes in 1952
Harold H. Nason purchases Rancho del Lago in Vail
events.description: Harold Nason plans to develop the property into a combination cattle and luxury guest ranch. Nason also owns the Westward Look resort in Tucson. Accommodations for 20 are available at Rancho del Lago. The purchase is comprised of 1,850 acres of patented land.

events.title: Kentucky Camp investors experience issues; mining ceases
events.description: Kentucky Camp's Stetson dies in fall from Santa Rita Hotel window in Tucson on May 20th; McAneny begins lengthy divorce proceedings. No further gold mining takes place.
events.source: McAneny begins lengthy divorce proceedings. Arizona Daily Star. May 21, 1905.

events.title: Horizon Corporation purchases Rancho del Lago in Vail
events.description: Joseph Timon, president of Horizon Corporation, plans to develop housing and a golf course on the site.

events.title: Vail Valley Ranch development plans approved
events.description: Vail Valley Ranch development plans approved by Pima County Board of Supervisors

events.title: Vail Historic Preservation Plan created
events.description: Vail Preservation Society works with the University of Arizona and the National Park Service to complete a historic preservation plan for Vail.

events.title: Preservation Youth Projects (PYP) begin
events.description: Cienega High School Construction Tech students begin working on the rehabilitation of a 1915 railroad section foreman house, which has been relocated to Esmond Station K8. Pantano High School students begin processing collections, Esmond Station K8 students conduct oral histories.

events.title: Kentucky Camp's Santa Rita Water and Mining Company sold
events.description: Kentucky Camp's Santa Rita WMCo sold at Sheriff's Sale
events.source: Orell FL. Kentucky Camp and the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company. Kentucky Camp Chronicle {Newsletter]. 1998. February

events.title: Antiquities Act
events.description: Antiquities Act preserves prehistoric, historic, & scientifically significant sites, creates national monuments; (Pub.L. 59–209, 34 Stat. 225, 16 U.S.C. § 431–433), signed into law by T Roosevelt. This law gives the President the authority to, by presidential proclamation, create national monuments from public lands to protect significant natural, cultural or scientific features. By 2017, the Act has been used over a hundred times since its passage, sometimes controversially.

events.title: Huachuca Forest Reserve established
events.description: In the following year, Huachuca Forest Reserve is redesignated the Huachuca National Forest. Later, the Forest is combined with Tumacacori and Baboquivari NFs to form the Garces National Forest on July 2 1908. The Garces is added to the Coronado National Forest on July 1, 1911. Federal lands in T21S, R18E set aside as Huachuca Forest Reserve. These lands are later transferred to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch.
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Santa Rita Forest Ranger Armour Scholefield dies
events.description: First Santa Rita Forest Ranger Armour Scholefield, stationed at Rosemont, dies of typhoid fever at age 23.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Walter Vail, founder of the Empire Ranch, dies
events.description: Walter Vail killed in a streetcar accident in Los Angeles. Management of the Empire Ranch continues under the direction of Carroll W. Gates and Vail family members.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: William Banning Vail arrives at the Empire Ranch
events.description: William Banning Vail, Walter Vail's son, is sent to the Empire Ranch to learn the business and eventually take over operations.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Economic depression halts Rosemont mining
events.description: Economic depression halts most copper mining operations in Arizona, including Rosemont.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont Administrative Site withdrawn from public entry
events.description: Rosemont: Rosemont Administrative Site withdrawn from public entry (no homestead claims allowed).
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Forest reserves renamed National Forests
events.description: Congress passes the Receipts Act of March 4 1907, renaming the Forest reserves as National Forests.
events.source: Harrison A. The Santa Catalinas: A Description and History. Tucson, AZ:Coronado National Forest; 1969

events.title: Colonel Potter surveys private lands not available for homestead
events.description: Survey to identify the boundaries of private lands that are not available for homesteading by settlers moving into the AZ territory; done by cadastral land surveyors working for the General Land Office
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Coronado National Forest established
events.description: The Coronado National Forest is established in 1908 from combination of several local Forests in Southeast Arizona and Southwest New Mexico.

events.title: Fire destroys Vail Store & Post Office (Schley's Store).
events.description: The store is rebuilt and open for business by August 1908. The origin of the fire is unknown. The store is the largest of the country stores in the area, serving Helvetia camp and other mining camps as well as local ranches and Southern Pacific Railroad workers.
events.source: Lamb JJ. The Old Vail Post Office, Connecting the Greater Vail Community Since 1908. The Smoke Signal. The Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2011. 90

events.title: Santa Rita National Forest is merged into Coronado National Forest
events.description: The Whetstone Mountains are added to the Santa Rita National Forest in 1907. Both ranges along with the Santa Catalina and the Rincon Mountains become the Coronado National Forest in 1908. Other National Forests are added to Coronado in following years.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Telephone installed at Vail's Siding
events.description: The Helvetia Mining Company pays for the cost of a long distance telephone line from Vail to Helvetia.
events.source: Helvetia Mining Company. Annual Report. Helvetia, AZ: Helvetia Mining Company; 1910

events.title: Santa Cruz County Fair and Rodeo Association formed
events.description: Santa Cruz County Fair and Rodeo Association forms

events.title: JP Smith, AZ hydrologist, designs subsurface dam on Lower Cienega Creek
events.description: J.P. Smith, Arizona's first hydrologist designs a subsurface dam, an artificial dam, on lower Cienega Creek near Rancho del Lago (today). The dam increases the flow up into Cienega Creek. The concrete arched dam remains today.
events.source: Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Kentucky Camp acquired by Louis Hummel for cattle ranching
events.description: Kentucky Camp. Louis Hummel acquires the property. Begins using it for cattle ranching
events.source: Doumas, M. Kentucky Camp Interpretive Plan. Personal communication.May 10, 2013.

events.title: El Paso and Southwestern Railroad extends from Benson to Tucson
events.description: By October 1912 the track surfacing gang is at Vail and heading towards Tucson. They span Cienega Creek with a 536-foot steel bridge near Irene Crossing
events.source: David Myrick. Railroads of Arizona. Volume 1. The Southern Roads. Berkeley, CA: Howell North Books; 1975

events.title: Cadastral land survey of public domain south of Babocomari Grant
events.description: General Land Office cadastral land survey of public lands south of Babocomari Grant delineates townships and sections for homestead claims.
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Arizona granted statehood
events.description: Arizona Statehood Act gives title to all unreserved Sections 2, 16,32 & 35 in each township for 'school sections' to be held in Trust for support of a public school system. Title of Section 16 (NW corner of Research Ranch) passes to the State
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Empire Ranch's William Banning Vail marries Laura Perry
events.description: William Banning Vail marries Tucsonan Laura Perry.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: WWI
Otto Schley, Vail Postmaster and first mayor, dies
events.description: Otto Schley is last seen on December 10, 1914.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Narragansett claim sold
