events.description: Rosemont: J.K. Brown sells Narragansett claim to William Ramsdell.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: National Park Service established
events.description: National Park Service established to administer national parks and monuments.

events.title: Severe drought
events.description: “…very severe climatic conditions caused an extraordinary high mortality among cattle” ; '...many stockmen being compelled to drive their cattle into Sonora where grass was more plentiful”
events.source:
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55
Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38
Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:15

events.title: F.C. Fenderson patent granted (future Research Ranch)
events.description: Patent to Frances Cuthbert Fenderson granted (portion of what becomes the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch).
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: National Park Service Organic Act
Stock Raising Homestead Act amended Homestead Act for ranchers
events.description: Stock Raising Homestead Act (an amendment to Homestead Act) passed to enable ranchers to acquire land without cultivation. Act authorizes 640 acre homesteads; separates surface from mineral rights
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Pancho Villa raids New Mexico
events.description: America enters the World War I

events.title: Narragansett Copper Company incorporated
events.description: Rosemont: Narragansett Copper Co. incorporated with W.R. Ramsdell as president.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Titus homestead patent (Research Ranch)
events.description: Patent of T.B.Titus homestead (currently headquarters of the National Audubon Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch)
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: The first use of the name Colossal Cave in print
events.description: Alfred Trippel, businessman, and US Forest Ranger Jim Westfall determine to promote and develop 'as a natural wonder of the district' what is suddenly called in print 'Colossal Cave'. Prior to this, it has been known as 'Five-mile Cave' or 'Five-mile Cave at Mountain Springs', and the 'Arizona Catacombs'.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Albert Steinfeld acquires the Narragansett Copper Company
events.description: Rosemont: Albert Steinfeld acquires the Narragansett to satisfy his claims against the company.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: The Arizona surface water code is enacted
events.description: Early in its history, Arizona adopts the doctrine of prior appropriation to govern the use of surface water. This doctrine is based on the tenet of “first in time, first in right” which means that the person who first puts the water to a beneficial use acquires a right that has a higher priority than later appropriators of the water. Prior to June 12, 1919, a person could acquire a surface water right simply by applying the water to a beneficial use and posting a notice of the appropriation at the point of diversion. On June 12, 1919, the Arizona surface water code is enacted. Now known as the Public Water Code, this law provides that a person must apply for and obtain a permit in order to appropriate surface water unless: 1. The water is from the mainstream of the lower Colorado river, in which case a contract with the Secretary of the Interior is required. 2.The person or the person’s predecessor-in-interest, lawfully appropriated the water prior to June 12, 1919 and the person or the person’s predecessor-in-interest has filed a statement of claim for the appropriation with the state. 3.The water is stored in a stock pond constructed after June 12, 1919 and before August 27, 1977.

events.title: Limited and intermittent mining operations at Rosemont
events.description: Rosemont: Limited and intermittent operations occur at the Rosemont mines.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Turbine pumps come to Tucson Basin and Cienega
events.description: Once fossil fuel becomes available to make using pumps practical, turbine pumps are adopted in the Tucson Basin in the 1910s and later at Cienega Creek. These pumps are important because water could be pumped from much deeper areas.
events.source: Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: AZ Game and Fish start releasing bullfrogs across the state
events.description: Bullfrogs are not native to Arizona, and negatively impact many species, in particular garter snakes and leopard frogs.

events.title: Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 passed
events.description: Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 30 U.S.C. § 181 et seq. authorizes and governs leasing of public lands for developing deposits of coal, petroleum, natural gas and other hydrocarbons, in addition to phosphates, sodium, sulfur, and potassium on public lands in the US. Previous to the act, these materials were subject to mining claims under the General Mining Act of 1872. Act requires that royalties be collected to provide funds for states, the US treasury and a Reclamation Fund.

events.title: The Roosevelt conservation movement
events.description: http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/amrvhtml/cnchron4.html

events.title: Jane Woods's mother describes major snow storm and drought
events.description: Jane Woods's mother, a teacher in the area, writes diary entries about her experience during one snow storm: so deep that her horse has to be led by other horses to reach her home. This is a drought time when cattle have to be driven into Mexico for food. Jane reveals this story March 17, 2012 at the Elgin Club during a 'Back Then' potluck.
events.source:
Woods J. Diary entries of my mom. Personal communication.Mar. 17, 2012.
Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:57

events.title: J.L. Finley Patents (future Research Ranch)

events.title: Frank Schmidt runs the first guided tours into Colossal Cave
events.description: These tours consist of outfitting his guests with ropes and lanterns and leading them through the unimproved passageways. Women were advised to wear bloomers (for modesty). As time went by, Schmidt strung a few electric light bulbs on a bare wire and put in some wooden steps and pathways. He never ceased exploring in the Cave.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Border Patrol begins and eventually expands operations in the Southwest
events.description: The U.S. Border Patrol is founded on May 28, 1924, as an agency of the United States Department of Labor to prevent illegal entries along the Mexico–United States border and the United States-Canada border.

events.title: Drought
events.source:

events.title: Pima County Board of Supervisors accepts Colossal Cave Road as a public highway
events.description: Eleven Vail residents petition the Pima County Board of Supervisors to accept 6.2 miles of Colossal Cave Road as a public highway beginning at Vail where Colossal Cave Road and the road to Benson intersect.
events.source: Pima County Collection. Papers. Arizona Historical Society, MS0183.1864-1985.

events.title: Human remains are found along Cienega Creek
events.description: Bryon Cummings, director of the Arizona State Museum excavates two burials exposed by erosion along Cienega Creek, 3.75 meters below the modern ground surface. Based on this depth, Cummings assigns an ancient date.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:58

events.description: Vails sell the Empire Ranch to Frank and Henry Boice, who start selling off portions of it. One of the buyers is Pete McDaniel, who also buys Mountain Springs Ranch

events.title: Empire Ranch sold to Chiricahua Ranches Company
events.description: The Chiricahua Ranches Company, owned by Henry, Frank, and Charles Boice, purchases the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Frank and Mary Boice move to the Empire Ranch
events.description: Frank and Mary Boice and their young sons Frank (Pancho) and Robert (Bob) move to the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Great Depression
events.description: The Great Depression spans the late 1920s to the early 1940s. Factors include world-wide economic collapse, the US stock market crash and nation-wide drought, bank closures, agricultural failures. Recovery only achieved with the US entry into World War II.
events.source: Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont Ranger Station closed and relocated to Patagonia
events.description: Rosemont Ranger Station in the Santa Rita Mountains is closed and relocated to Patagonia around 1929
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Joe, Jr. and Jack Kennedy at J Six Ranch
events.description: Joe, Jr. and Jack Kennedy spend a summer during their teens; they assist in building a small adobe building.

events.title: Cienega Creek groundwater becomes public concern
events.description: Concern is that Cienega Creek may become one of the last perennial Arizona waters that is primarily groundwater-dependent

events.title: Mesquite encroachment out of washes and into grasslands accelerates
events.description: At the beginning of the 1900s, mesquite is largely confined to large washes above 1000m though early botanists note small plants within grasslands. Since 1930 mesquite cover and density rapidly increase. This loss of available grass for grazing leads to many different efforts by ranchers to physically remove or chemically poison individual mesquite plants.
events.source: McClaren M. A Century of Vegetation Change on the Santa Rita Experimental Range. Santa Rita Experimental Range: 100 Years (1903 to 2003) of Accomplishments and Contributions. Conference Proceedings. USDA Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station. RMRS-P-30.; Oct 30-Nov 1, 2003.

events.title: Thousands migrate across Arizona during Great Depression
events.description: Driven by the loss of jobs, homes, farms, and ranches, millions of people abandon their communities and travel westward looking for a different future. Most are hoping to find employment in the farm fields in California. Those affected by the early economic downturn begin arriving in Arizona in 1930. A nation-wide drought and the resulting Dust Bowl drive even more westward during the mid-1930s. By then many earlier transients are leaving CA and migrating again eastward. This pattern of movement continues until the US economy recovers and employment rises dramatically as the country gears up for war in the early 1940s.
events.source:
Williams J. Before the New Deal: Private Charity and Government Efforts to Help the Poor in Tucson, 1929-1933. Journal of Arizona History. Summer 2009. 50(2):103-124
Weisiger, M. Mythic Fields of Plenty. The Plight of Depression-Era Oklahoma Migrants in Arizona. Journal of Arizona History. Autumn 1991. 32(3):241-266

events.title: AZ cotton decision giving all rights to groundwater

events.title: Wild horses collected during droughts

events.title: Civilian Conservation Corps work in Southern Arizona
events.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps working under the US Forest Service construct hundreds of miles of drift fences and numerous water developments on Coronado National Forest. Allotments with relatively light stocking rates show marked improvement. The goal of these developments and fencing is to increase range capacity and management.
events.source: Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20

events.title: Cattleman Charles (Chay) Day buys Mountain Springs Ranch from Pete McDaniel
events.description: Day renames the ranch 'La Posta Quemada Ranch'; he builds a headquarters house at the site of the old adobe Mountain Springs Hotel, incorporating some of the structure.

events.title: Federal farm bill created to support agriculture
events.description: In the United States, the farm bill is the primary agricultural and food policy tool of the federal government. The comprehensive omnibus bill is passed every 5 years or so by the United States Congress and deals with both agriculture and all other affairs under the purview of the United States Department of Agriculture. The farm bill is first created during the Great Depression to give financial assistance to farmers who are struggling due to an excess crop supply creating low prices, and also to control and ensure an adequate food supply. The first farm bill, known as the Agriculture Adjustment Act (AAA), is passed by Congress in 1933 as a part of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal. The bill allows farmers to receive payment for not growing food on a percentage of their land as allocated by the United States Secretary of Agriculture. It also enables the government to buy excess grain from farmers, which can then be sold later if bad weather or other circumstances negatively affect output. The AAA also includes a nutrition program, the precursor to food stamps.

events.title: Pantano Creek Waters and Tributaries Rights Determination Case
events.description: Tattersfield vs. Putnam in the matter of determination of the relative rights to the waters of Pantano Creek and its tributaries in Pima County. T16S, R16E, Gila and Salt River Base and Meridian. Cleaveland Putnam's right to use five acre feet of water per annum for stock and domestic purposes and for irrigation upon 128.842 acres of land.

events.title: Saguaro National Monument transferred to National Park Service from US Forest Service

events.source: Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.description: Widespread drought; in June, AZ declared a drought state, S AZ counties declared emergency areas

events.title: Taylor Grazing Act passed to regulate access for grazing on public lands
events.description: Taylor Grazing Act of 1934 authorizes grazing districts and regulations on public lands. (Pub.L. 73–482) (excluding Alaska) to It was the first national law to provide for regulated control of the unappropriated grazing land. The act is intended to help prevent overgrazing and erosion.improve rangeland conditions and regulate their use; administered by the Department of the Interior. As amended, the law applies to approximately 162,000,000 ac inside grazing allotments. These can be vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved land from public lands, all except for Alaska, national forests, parks, monuments, Indian reservations, railroad grant lands, etc. Permits are given for grazing privileges in the districts.; or to build fences, reservoirs, and other improvements. Permittees are required to pay a fee; permit cannot exceed ten years but is renewable. Permits can be revoked because of severe drought or other natural disasters that deplete grazing lands..
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Frank Schmidt relinquishes his Colossal Cave leases to the state of Arizona
events.description: Frank Schmidt, leaseholder and caretaker of Colossal Cave, wants the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) to develop the Cave. However, CCC projects are restricted to the development of public properties. Colossal Cave, although on public land, is a commercial enterprise on land leased to a private individual and is therefore not eligible for a CCC project. When the CCC becomes active in Southern Arizona, Schmidt, the Pima County Board of Supervisors, the State Land Bureau, and the Tucson Chamber of Commerce unite in efforts to make Colossal Cave a public property. Schmidt gives up his State leases so that the area can be under the control of a government agency, and Colossal Cave becomes a State Park and is thus eligible to be a Civilian Conservation Corps Public Park Improvement Project. CCC Camp SP-10-A is authorized.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Civilian Conservation Corps working in Colossal Cave Park
events.description: The Colossal Cave Project is overseen by the National Park Service.By May of 1934, the Colossal Cave Project has been authorized, and the CCC are on site, to spend four years there. The first CCC personnel to work at Colossal Cave are Company 0858. Originally from Wyoming, these CCC-ers are assigned to Camp SP-1-A at Randolph Park in Tucson in late October or early November, 1933. On May 5, 1934, instead of being transferred back to Wyoming for the summer, they are assigned duties at the new Colossal Cave state park. At first they continue to live at Camp SP-1-A and are driven back and forth to Colossal Cave each day. By February 1, 1935, they have set up a “fly camp” and are living in tents on La Posta Quemada Ranch immediately to the south of the Cave at Camp SP-10-A, the camp for the Colossal Cave Project.The men work on trails, handrails, and lighting in the Cave, and some construction of the barracks camp that follows them. In May of 1935, the fly camp is disbanded, and Company 0858 is transferred back to Camp SP-1-A, and from there to Wyoming. On August 19, 1935, Second Lieutenant J. Filbrun and twelve enrollees, forming a cadre from Camp NP-2-A, Grand Canyon, Arizona, arrive at Colossal Cave. First Lieutenant Alfred H. Johnson, the initial commander, greets the cadre. By August 22, 1935, enrollees from Texas and Arizona make up the company strength and Company 2851 is established at Camp SP-10-A. In the Cave, they widen passages, lay flagstone pathways, install handrails and lighting, and enlarge the entrance. Above ground, they construct the hewn-limestone retaining wall and Headquarters building, including the doors and shutters (and hardware) and furniture. After the work in the Cave and on the buildings is completed, the CCC personnel create the picnic areas; they build roads and several more stone structures, including the barbecue ramada in La Selvilla Picnic Area and the pumphouse.
events.source:
Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000:
Hunt SE, Lamb JJ, Maierhauser M. Civilian Conservation Corps Scrapbook: Camp SP-10-A Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Tucson, AZ: Colossal Cave Mountain Park; 2012

events.title: WPA project number #274 to classify all state lands
events.description: WPA project # 274 is assigned to classify all State Trust lands. The project includes a physical examination of the state grazing lands 1) to determine leasing values, 2) to draft a topographical map for each township to show different land ownership and 3) to estimate the carrying capacity, rainfall amounts and soil conditions.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:73

events.title: Tucson Plant Material Center established
events.description: Tucson Plant Material Center established for erosion control under Soil Conservation Service. FJ Crider imports Lehmann lovegrass and other nonnative grasses from South Africa for testing for erosion control and range revegetation in SE AZ.
events.source: Crider FJ. Three Introduced Lovegrasses for Soil Conservation. US Department of Agriculture Circular 730; 1945

events.title: Soil Conservation Service established
events.description: The agency is founded largely through the efforts of Hugh Hammond Bennett, a soil conservation pioneer who had worked for the Department of Agriculture from 1903 to 1952. Bennett's motivation is based on his knowledge of the detrimental effects of soil erosion and the impacts on U.S lands that led to the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. On September 13, 1933, the Soil Erosion Service is formed in the Department of the Interior, with Bennett as chief. The service is transferred to the Department of Agriculture on March 23, 1935, and is shortly thereafter combined with other USDA units to form the Soil Conservation Service by the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1935. Hugh Bennett continues as chief, a position he holds until his retirement in 1952. On October 20, 1994, the agency is renamed to the Natural Resources Conservation Service as part of the Federal Crop Insurance Reform and Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994.

events.title: Shrine of Santa Rita in the Desert dedicated in Vail
events.description: Built by Caroline Takamine Beach for the poor Hispanic ranching families, the Shrine honors Caroline's first husband, Japanese scientist Jokichi Takamine. Architects are H.D.R. Figge and D. Burr DuBois
events.source: National Register of Historic Places Nomination. Shrine of Santa Rita in the Desert. Nomination number: 14001231.Dec 7, 2015.

events.title: First aerial photographs of Cienega Watershed
events.description: First aerial photographs of Cienega Watershed to look at soil erosion by the Soil Conservation Service (now Natural Resources Conservation Service). Comparison with modern aerial photographs show that the arroyo has reached approximate depth of modern day but widening continues
events.source: Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Certificate of water right to divert Cienega Creek at dam
events.description: Granted.

events.title: Federal soil erosion program established
events.description: The Federal soil erosion program is a partnership between the state of Arizona and the Soil Conservation Service. The program is designed to check deterioration of the ranges by planting suitable vegetation and to restore the land to its previous carrying capacity.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:73

events.title: Soil Conservation Range Benefit Program
events.description: Agricultural Adjustment Administration announces the Soil Conservation Range Benefit Program designed to encourage range improvement and erosion mitigation through better stock distributions. Funds available to develop fences, dirt dams, stock tanks, and wells. By the summer 1937, 450 Arizona ranchers were co-operating.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:61

events.title: Lehmann lovegrass introduced on Santa Rita Experimental Range
events.description: Lehmann lovegrass introduced on Santa Rita Experimental Range.
events.source: Cable DR . Lehmann Lovegrass in the Santa Rita Experimental Range,1937-1968 . Journal of Range Management. 1971. 24:17-21

events.title: Brush occurrence survey
events.description: During the 1930s, the encroachment of shrubs receives attention. A survey of “Occurrence of Shrubs on Range Areas in South-eastern Arizona” is conducted in 1937, and finds the expanding of shrubs is almost universal throughout Southern Arizona. Mesquite is found to be the most widespread species. Several tests on techniques of killing shrubs are conducted in 1940s.
events.source: Sayre N.. The cattle boom in Southern Arizona: towards a critical political ecology. Journal of the Southwest. 1999. 41(2):239-271

events.title: Grazing Region 9 established (Phoenix) by mid-1937
events.description: Organized under the Taylor Grazing Act of 1934 and managed by the Grazing Service, early version of the Bureau of Land Management

events.title: The Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act
Range Conservation Program
events.description: Range Conservation Program is designed to encourage deferred grazing by removing cattle from grassland until grasses reach maturity. Program encourages development of erosion mitigation through water spreading, gully stopping, and improvements of grassland potential through spring development and the eradication of cactus, saltcedar and mesquite.
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:62

events.title: Dry season
events.source: Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:115

events.title: La Posta Quemada Ranch enlarged from combined lands
events.description: Charles (Chay) Day combines federal and state grazing leases with patented lands to enlarge La Posta Quemada Ranch; working lands total 33,000 acres on which Day runs 600 head of cattle.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: World War 2
events.description: World War 2 was a global conflict that involved countries from all continents but was fought primarily in Europe, Africa and Asia. It was initiated on Spetember 9 1939 when Nazi Germany invaided Poland and ended when Japan surrendered on August 15, 1945 after the US dropped a second nuclear weapon on the city of Nagasaki. The US entered the war in December 1941 following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in Hawaii.

events.title: Seasonal droughts
events.source: Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:44

events.title: Lehmann Lovegrass and Boer Lovegrass planted on Babocomari Ranch
events.description: Lehmann Lovegrass and Boer Lovegrass (exotic grasses from Africa) are planted on Babocomari Ranch by U.S. Soil Conservation Service as range improvement. S LL: Non-natives species can cause trouble for native ecosystems
events.source: Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Earliest Cienega Creek baseline streamflow measurements
events.description: Leonard Halpenny makes base flow measurements, the earliest on lower Cienega Creek
events.source: Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Empirita Ranch established
events.description: Empirita established when it is broken from the Empire Ranch in 1941. Pima County begins purchasing portions east of Tucson and south of I-10.

events.title: Severely dry
events.source: Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38

events.title: The Audubon Whittell Research Ranch state land auction
events.description: Arizona State Land Department auctions 2 parcels of County Bond Trust lands in T21S,R18E (Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch): 320 acres of Section 17 to N.E. Clark; 40 acres Section 23 to Willard T. Roath.
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008.

events.title: Pima County leases Colossal Cave Park from the State Land Department
events.description: Pima County leases Colossal Cave Park from the State Land Department and names Frank Schmidt Supervisor. He continues to operate the Park, personally or through managers until age 84.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Conservation Needs Inventory focuses on soils and water
events.description: By the early 1940s, The Soil Conservation Service (SCS) realizes natural resources information is required to develop programs and set priorities for various conservation needs throughout the country. After assembling and analyzing the available resources data, SCS publishes in 1945 a report on U.S. soil and water conservation needs, which becomes the Conservation Needs Inventory (CNI) and prepares the ground for future inventories.
events.source:
Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008:1-3,5-6
Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000:3-4

events.title: Hollywood filming comes to the Watershed
events.description: 1946 Duel in the Sun, 1948 Red River; 1959 Last Train from Gun Hill; Gunsmoke, Bonanza; almost 50 movies

events.title: US Grazing Service ended; becomes Bureau of Land Management
events.description: BLM is created by Congress through the merger of the General Land Office, the Grazing Service, and the Oregon and California Railroad (O&C) Revested Lands Administration

events.title: Drought conditions
events.source: Duncklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38

events.title: Cienega Valley systematically surveyed for prehistoric sites
events.description: Earl Swanson, University of Arizona student, undertakes the first systematic survey of Cienega valley for his Master's thesis. He discovers many ceramic and preceramic period sites.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Red River filmed at the Empire Ranch
events.description: Red River, starring John Wayne, is filmed at the Empire Ranch and other local locations.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Cloud seeding attempted
events.description: An attempt at cloud seeding is initiated by local ranchers; the program runs from June 15-September 30. A.C. Barnes of the Precipitation Control Company is hired to do the job, but produces inconclusive results.
events.source: Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:39

events.title: Huachuca House installed at the Empire Ranch
events.description: A remodeled surplus building from the army base at Ft. Huachuca is installed west of the Empire Ranch House as a home for Bob and Miriam Boice.
events.source: The Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2015

events.title: Arizona drought disaster declared
events.source: Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:44

events.title: Banner Mining Co. acquires Twin Butte Mine; begins exploration in Helvetia District
events.description: Banner Mining Co. acquires Twin Butte Mine; begins exploration in Helvetia District. Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Prairie dogs disappear
events.description: Black tailed prairie dogs extirpated from AZ by 1961
events.source: Hoffmeister DF. Mammals of Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1986

events.title: Pronghorn antelope disappear
events.description: pronghorn extirpated from Valley 1950s likely
events.source: Hoffmeister DF. Mammals of Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1986

events.title: A deep long-lasting drought
events.description: Deep long-lasting drought

events.title: Frank and Mary Boice become sole owners of the Empire Ranch
events.description: Frank and Mary Boice become sole owners of the Empire Ranch, formerly owned by the Chiricahua Ranches Company. Empire Cattle Company is created; partners are Frank, Mary, Frank Stephen (Pancho), and Bob Boice.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Rooms in the Victorian Addition of the Empire Ranch House remodeled
events.description: Rooms in the Victorian Addition of the Empire Ranch House remodeled by Frank and Mary Boice.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Evidence of early maize agriculture discovered
events.description: In Cienega Creek alluvial sediments dated stratigraphically to the same period as EE:2:30, Paul Martin and James Schoenwetter discover pollen evidence of early maize agriculture.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: In Mattie Canyon, excavation of a San Pedro stage preceramic site
events.description: Frank Eddy excavates preceramic site AZ EE:2:30 buried over 5 meters in the alluvium but exposed on the channel floor of Mattie Wash. Rich in remains, Eddy terms this a San Pedro phase, Cochise cultural base camp.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Stratigraphy and archaeological sites surveyed along Cienega Creek and Mattie Canyon
events.description: Frank Eddy, U of Arizona student, records the alluvial stratigraphy and ceramic and preceramic sites along Mattie Canyon and Cienega Creek. Eddy applies a unique interdisciplinary approach to archaeological research. He collaborates with a geologist, palynologist and malacologist. Eddy's work demonstrates the rich cultural history spanned more than 3,000 years and that spatial patterning of sites could be tied to changes in the floodplain environment.
events.source:
Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2
Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Bob Boice moves to Globe, AZ to manage the Slash S ranch
events.description: Bob and Miriam Boice and their children move to Globe, AZ to manage the Slash S ranch.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Drought period
events.source:
Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:86
Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:22

events.title: Drought conditions
events.source: Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38

events.title: Wild Cow fire
Colossal Cave Park is sublet by Pima County to a private partnership
events.description: In an arrangement unique for a public park, Colossal Cave Park is sublet to Joe Maierhauser and Earl Brockelsby, businessmen experienced in tourism; this is a lease of the entire park, not a concession agreement. It is also unique in that Pima County itself is leasing the Park from the Arizona State Land Department.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Frank Seymour Boice dies
events.description: Frank Seymour Boice dies. Management of the Empire is taken over by his sons Frank Stephen (Pancho) and Bob.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Mary Boice leaves the Empire Ranch
events.description: Mary Boice remarries and relocates.
events.source: The Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2015

events.title: La Posta Quemada Ranch sold
events.description: Charles Day sells La Posta Quemada Ranch to Joseph Timan, investor and developer, who sells to Orel Burris, a cattleman and entrepreneur
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Severely dry winters
events.source: Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:1

events.title: Deer Spring fire
Appletons purchase Clark Ranch (future Research Ranch)
events.description: Frank and Ariel Appleton purchase the Clark Ranch (later to become the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch)
events.source: Braun B. Ecology Goes to the Country. Tucson, Arizona: Sunday Star-Citizen. September 6, 1970.

events.title: Wild Horse Protection Act
Box fire
Hummel fire
Diggins fire
Proposal to dam Cienega Creek at Benson highway bridge
events.description: For an industrial complex and lake. Proposal never happens, but creates a legacy of zoning in the area that is only repealed with the establishment of Las Cienegas

events.title: Public Sale Patent to Appletons (future Research Ranch)
events.description: Public Sale Patent No. 1215504 to Francis Henry Appleton (lots 4 & 5 adjacent to Homestead Patent No. 855360) at future Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch [Audubon]
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Hummels stop ranching; sell property to Anamax Mining Co
events.description: The last Hummels (Floss and Wert Fenter) stop ranching and sell the property to Anamax Mining Company. Kentucky Camp, Orell 1998
events.source: Orell FL. Kentucky Camp and the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company. Kentucky Camp Chronicle {Newsletter]. 1998. February

events.title: Public Land Administration Act allows donations and cooperative agreements
events.description: Public Land Administration Act increases the federal government's ability to partner through cooperative agreements as well as to accept donations.

events.title: Multiple Use Sustained Yield Act
Federal Civil Defense Department names Colossal Cave as fallout shelter
events.description: The Federal Civil Defense Department names Colossal Cave a fallout shelter, slated for use by Pima County and City of Tucson government officials. Boxes of food and barrels of water stored in Cave's Side Routes.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Bureau of Land Management Arizona State Office created
events.description: BLM has re-organized multiple times but in 1961, it creates a state office system. The Arizona State Office is created to oversee Arizona public lands. AZ State Director: Fred J. Weiler 1961 - 1970
events.source: Public Lands Foundation. Historical Record of the Offices, Managers and Organizations of the U. S. Bureau of Land Management, Grazing Service, General Land Office and O&C Revested Lands Administration 1934 - 2012. Phoenix, AZ: Public Lands Foundation; April 2012

events.title: Land Exchange to Frank Appleton from Forest Service
events.description: Land Exchange Patent 02-62-0119 to Frank Appleton (1076 acres in Sections 27,28 - the Audubon Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch) from U.S. Forest Service (3rd party exchange)
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Anaconda Company pursues lease agreement with Banner Mining Co.
events.description: Anaconda Company enters into lease agreement with Banner Mining Co. Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Mustang fire
Whetstone fire
Radio Corporation of America proposes satellite city near Lower Cienega Creek
events.description: Pima County Comprehensive Plan accommodates a giant development to support RCA, a large entertainment and communication corporation at that time. The development involves placing a dam at the Benson Hwy bridge with a resulting lake. The development does not happen but the area remains classified as an industrial zone until removed by the Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan (Pima County).
events.source: Fonseca J.. Cienega Watershed Shared History Part Three. Personal Communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Joe Maierhauser becomes sole proprietor of Colossal Cave Park sublease
events.description: Joe and his partner, Earl Brockelsby, dissolve their Colossal Cave Park partnership, and Joe becomes sole proprietor of the operation.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Wilderness Act
events.description: The Wilderness Act created the National Wilderness Preservation System and was designed to provide an additional layer of protection to public lands that remain relatively unaltered including those under NPS, USFS, BLM and USFWS. The act restricts specific types of uses and alterations to the landscapes and creates protections for both natural and cultural resources present at the time of wilderness area establishment.

events.title: Discoveries of deeply buried archaeological remains along Cienega Creek
events.description: E. Thomas Hemmings, M.D., Robinson and R.N. Rogers recover burials exposed in a vertical face below over 5 meters of alluvium. Site EE:2:50.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.

events.title: Tovrea conveys the Swinging H Ranch to Bryce Appleton
events.description: Harold C. Tovrea conveys the Swinging H Ranch (in Sections 14,13,23,27 T21S,R18E) to Ariel Bryce Appleton ---Deed recorded in Santa Cruz County, AZ. Dock 064, Page 98-100
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Land and Water Conservation Fund
events.description: Federal fund established in 1965 to provide funds and matching grants to federal agencies, state and local governments to acquire and protect important lands and waters to achieve cultural, natural, wildlife, and recreational management objectives. Congressional funding has declined significantly since its start.

events.title: Phoenix District BLM Office established
events.description: Includes Tucson BLM-managed lands

events.title: Fire on La Posta Quemada Ranch destroys headquarters house
events.description: Another fire on La Posta Quemada Ranch destroys the headquarters house that had been built in the 1930s by Charles Day on the site of Solomon Lick's Mountain Springs Hotel. Colossal Cave Mountain Park's Mountain Springs Grove Picnic Area is located here today.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000
