events.title: Rosemont fire
National Historic Preservation Act expands site protection
events.description: The Act (NHPA) (Public Law 89-665; 16 U.S.C. 470 et seq.) preserves historical and archaeological sites; creates the National Register of Historic Places, the list of National Historic Landmarks, and the State Historic Preservation Offices.

events.title: Gila topminnow first listed as Endangered
events.description: Gila topminnow fish first listed as Endangered on the Federal Endangered Species Act list. The Cienega Creek location remains a top location for this fish.

events.title: John S. Sullivan buys La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: John S. Sullivan buys La Posta Quemada Ranch, reinstates it as a working cattle ranch, builds new headquarters house near the corrals, which is also near where the CCC camps had been located.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Apache fire
Williams fire
Central Arizona Project authorized
events.description: After 22 years of advocacy by the Central Arizona Project Association, President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the bill authorizing funds for the construction of the Central Arizona Project aqueduct. The Department of the Interior and the Bureau of Reclamation are assigned to fund and construct the project.
events.source: Central Arizona Project. About Us: History. 2015.

events.title: Cattle removed from the Elgin Hereford Cattle Ranch
events.description: Research Ranch
events.source: Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: National Wild and Scenic Rivers System/Wild and Scenic Rivers Act
Canelo Hills Cienega Preserve purchased by The Nature Conservancy
events.description: Canelo Hills Cienega Preserve purchased by The Nature Conservancy; Patagonia-Sonoita creek preserve around same time

events.title: Empire Ranch satellite city proposal creates conflict
events.description: In early 1970s, Gulf America Corporation plans for satellite city of 180,000 people in the Sonoita Valley. Local residents and county officials express concern regarding effects of proposed development on natural resources.
events.source:
Fonseca J.. Cienega Watershed Shared History Part Three. Personal Communication.Nov. 2012.
McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: Gulf American Corporation purchases Empire Ranch
events.description: Pancho Boice sells Empire Ranch to Gulf American Corp. GAC planned to develop a community for over 180,000 residents spanning the area from the Empire Ranch south to the town of Sonoita. Pima County refuses to approve the proposal which threatens water supplies for communities downstream. During the interim, the Frank Stephen (Pancho) Boice and his son Steve continue to reside at ranch and continue grazing cattle under a lease agreement with GAC.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Appleton Whittell Research Ranch incorporates as nonprofit
events.description: The Appleton-Whittell Research (of the National Audubon Society) Ranch incorporated as not-for-profit Arizona Corporation to manage the former Elgin Hereford Cattle Ranch (Appleton), Articles of Incorporation, Dock 106 Page 73, State of Arizona, Certificate of Incorporation #77060 issued 15 Sept 1969 by Milton Husky, Chairman, ACC; Appleton Research Ranch created, cattle removed, native grasses improve
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Anaconda Company pursues a Land Exchange to develop mining properties
events.description: Anaconda Company, as lessee of Banner, informs Coronado National Forest of its intent to pursue a Land Exchange to develop mining properties.Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Gulf America Corporation and later Anamax drill numerous wells in Cienega Valley
events.description: Gulf American Corp begins drilling wells throughout the Empire, testing for water availability. One of the first wells is at the west end of the air runway. Anamax Mining Co, following purchase of the Empire from GAC, continues to drill wells with the intent of using that water at its Rosemont mine.
events.source: Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Disney films and releases TV movie, The Outlaw Cats of Colossal Cave
events.description: The movie is the story of a mother bobcat and her kittens in Colossal Cave, and is very loosely based on the Cave Bandit Legend; all filming is done in and around the Park
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: National Environmental Policy Act
events.description: National Environmental Policy Act requires federal agencies to prepare environmental assessments or environmental impact statements that state the potential impacts of actions on environment. Enforcement occurs through the court system. Decisions are open to public review and comment.

events.title: The First Earth Day
Environmental Protection Agency established
events.description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA or sometimes USEPA) is an agency of the U.S. Federal government, created for the purpose of protecting human health and the environment by writing and enforcing regulations based on laws passed by Congress. The EPA is proposed by President Richard Nixon and begins operation on December 2, 1970, after Nixon signs an executive order.

events.title: Wild Horses and Burros Act
Clean Water Act
events.description: As amended in 1972, the law becomes known as the Clean Water Act (CWA). CWA establishes the basic structure for regulating discharges of pollutants into the waters of the US and regulating quality standards for surface waters. The basis for CWA is enacted in 1948 (the Federal Water Pollution Control Act), but the Act is significantly reorganized and expanded. The 1972 amendments: Establish the basic structure for regulating pollutant discharges into the waters of the United States. Gives the Environmental Protection Agency the authority to implement pollution control programs such as setting wastewater standards for industry.

events.title: Release of Black-tailed Prairie Dogs on the Research Ranch fails
events.description: Release of Black-tailed Prairie Dogs on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch fails. More info in the Research Ranch Annual Report August 31, 1972
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Dr. Jay Schnell becomes Research Ranch Director
events.description: Dr. Jay Schnell hired as Director of the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Nicholson completes first thesis on the Research Ranch
events.description: R.A. Nicholson completes the first thesis on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch: Grama (Bouteloua Lag.) Communities in a Southern Arizona Grassland
events.source: Nicholson RA . Grama (Bouteloua Lag.) Communities in a Southern Arizona Grassland (Thesis). ; 1972

events.title: Development work on La Posta Quemada Ranch expands CCMP programs and features
events.source: Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:45

events.title: Amax Mining Co. acquires Banner Mining Co.’s holdings, partners with Anaconda to create Anamax Mining Company
events.description: Amax acquires Banner Mining Co.’s holdings and with Anaconda creates Anamax Mining Company.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Anamax acquires Empire, Cienega, and VR Ranches
events.description: Anamax purchases the Empire Ranch from Gulf American Corporation in 1974. In 1977 Anamax acquires Ed Vail's VR Ranch in Rosemont Valley and the Cienega Ranch from Sam Bell. Anamax is interested in these ranches for their water rights and water supplies.
events.source:
Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.
Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Breeding program for endangered Bolson tortoise on the Research Ranch
events.description: Program established by Ariel Appleton for the exotic Bolson tortoise, a non-native to the area. Formally establishes a breeding program to support native populations elsewhere, mainly Mexico
events.source:
Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.
Appleton A. The Research Ranch, A Dream Becomes Reality. National Parks & Conservation Magazine. Dec 1973.

events.title: Vegetation changes (grasses) on the Research Ranch
events.description: On the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch (Elgin), vegetation shifts from short-grass to mid-grass prairie after 3 yrs without domestic livestock.
events.source: Bonham C . Vegetation Shifts. Newsweek. September 24, 1973.

events.title: Endangered Species Act
events.description: The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a 'consequence of economic growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation.' Endangered Species Act requires conservation of threatened and endangered plants, animals, ecosystems; the Act provides a framework for actions.
events.source: United States. Endangered Species Act of 1973. 16 US Code 1531 et seq.. Washington, DC: Government Printing Office; 1973

events.title: Empire Ranch's Frank (Pancho) Boice dies
events.description: Pancho Boice dies in a plane crash. His son Steve takes over sole responsibility for the operations on the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Empire Ranch House listed on National Register of Historic Places
events.description: Empire Ranch House listed on National Register of Historic places; submitted by Marjorie Wilson, Arizona State Parks
events.source: National Park Service. National Register of Historic Places. Website.2015.

events.title: Anamax initiates Land Exchange with Coronado National Forest
events.description: Anamax Mining Co. initiates Land Exchange with Coronado National Forest and enters into agreement with the University of Arizona for environmental analysis.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Safe Drinking Water Act
events.description: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) is established to protect the quality of drinking water in the U.S. This law focuses on all waters actually or potentially designated for drinking use, whether from above ground or underground sources.

events.title: Federal Noxious Weed Act
events.description: Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to declare some plants as noxious weeds and to limit Interstate movement without a permit. The act requires NPS, BLM, USFS, USFWS to develop integrated management programs.

events.title: Forest and Range Renewable Resources Planning Act passed
events.description: RPA requires the US Forest Service to conduct assessments on all renewable resources in forests and on rangelands including timber, grass, wildlife and fish, biodiversity, water, outdoor recreation, wilderness, urban forests, and effects of climate change on all resources.

events.title: Anamax Mining Company purchases the Empire Ranch
events.description: Anamax Mining Company purchases the Empire Ranch from Gulf American Corporation for its water rights and mineral potential.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Anamax archaeological surveys record 85 historic sites including Rosemont
events.description: To support the Anamax-Rosemont land exchange proposal, 30 square miles are surveyed on Forest Service lands and associated Anamax patented or fee lands between 1975 and 1982.Both old and newer Rosemont recorded.
events.source: Ayres J. The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) ; 1984

events.title: Boice family lease to manage the Empire Ranch discontinued
events.description: Boice family lease to manage the Empire Ranch discontinued by Anamax and the remaining Boice cattle are sold.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: John Donaldson leases the Empire Ranch
events.description: John Donaldson enters into a lease arrangement with Anamax to operate the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Survey and excavations for proposed Anamax Coronado National Forest land exchange
events.description: Arizona State Museum conducts a large-scale intensive survey and excavation project on the proposed land exchange between the Coronado National Forest and the Anamax Mining Corporation. Numerous Archaic, Hohokam, and historic sites near Rosemont are identified and excavated, greatly expanding archaeologists' understanding of the area.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Bomber Burn, fire on Research Ranch starts by aircraft jettison
events.description: Bomber Burn, fire on Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch starts by jettison from aircraft; At that time, Larry and Marsha Michel are Directors of the Research Ranch
events.source:
Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000
Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Empire Cienega Creek grazing practices change
events.description: John Donaldson begins ranching for Anamax, then grazing under a Bureau of Land Management permit. Lessons learned on best grazing and pasture rotation applied especially after 1988. These include fencing cattle out the creek and riparian wash area. These best practices, such as grazing rotation and fencing, help uplands and eventually damaged riparian areas along the Creek at Las Cienegas begin to recover.
events.source: McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: John S. Sullivan sells La Posta Quemada Ranch to Jack Lewis
events.description: John S. Sullivan sells La Posta Quemada to Jack Lewis, rancher and developer with dreams of condominiums and using the ranch as resort/guest ranch

events.title: Kelleys purchase land between the railroad tracks in Vail
events.description: Arthur and Mary Jane Kelley purchase the land between the railroad tracks in Vail including the Old Vail Post Office. The 1908 building is operated as Vail Feed Store until 1994.

events.title: Hannas move to Empirita Ranch to preserve Cienega Natural Preserve
events.description: Neal and Diana Hanna move from Empirita Ranch (Pantana Townsites), working cattle Ranch caretakers, to present Natural Preserve. Source of many creek observations such as: in 1975 new Tucson East Marsh Station and a lot of air smugglers landing in these areas
events.source: Hanna N, Hanna D. Shared History at Cienega Corridor Conservation Council Meeting. Personal Communication.May 4, 2013.

events.title: National Forest lands (355 acres) withdrawn for Research Natural Area
events.description: Public Land Order 5835 withdrew 355 acres of National Forest lands for Research Natural area (Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch) and withdrew this area from mining claims. (Section 26,T21S,R18E; Research Ranch)
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
events.description: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) gives EPA the authority to control hazardous waste from the 'cradle-to-grave.' This includes the generation, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous waste. RCRA also set forth a framework for the management of non-hazardous solid wastes. The 1986 amendments to RCRA enabled EPA to address environmental problems that could result from underground tanks storing petroleum and other hazardous substances.

events.title: Federal Land Policy and Management Act
events.description: Federal Land Policy and Management Act requires public lands be managed for multiple uses and sustained yield through land use planning
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: National Forest Management Act
events.description: NFMA is an amendment to the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 designed to enhance protection of forests from excessive and destructive logging and to develop regulations that limit the size of clearcuts, protect streams and soils, and ensure prompt reforestation based on Multiple-Use and Sustained-Yield principles. The Act requires implementation of a resource management plan for each forest unit.

events.title: Rosemont Environmental Impact Statement for Asarco Proposal
events.description: The Environmental Impact Statement is prepared by the University of Arizona for a proposed land exchange with National Forest lands and Asarco Mining Company

events.title: Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act passes
events.description: Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act ensures environmental safeguards of mining & reclamation
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Mac and Billie Donaldson partner with John Donaldson at Empire
events.description: John Donaldson's son Mac and his wife Billie move to the Empire Ranch to partner with John.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Public Rangelands Improvement Act
events.description: Public Rangelands Improvement Act requires inventory, trend analysis, improvements of public rangelands

events.title: Pronghorn reintroduced by Arizona Game and Fish Department into Cienega Watershed
events.description: (had been gone since 50/60s) – mix in species (grazing permittee Donaldson's allowed them to be introduced)

events.title: Archaeological Resources Protection Act passed
events.description: Archaeological Resources Protection Act requires permits for any excavation on public land, provides criminal, civil penalties for removal of artifacts or defacement of sites

events.title: Groundwater management act --- designates AMA boundaries
events.description: decision to exclude area of Rosemont mine (owned by Asarco), excludes portions of Davidson Canyon

events.title: Drs. Carl and Jane Bock direct Research Ranch
events.description: Drs. Carl and Jane Bock serve as Research Directors of the Research Ranch under contract to National Audubon Society. Vern Hawthorne is Resident Director of the Research Ranch
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: National Audubon Society renames the Appleton Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Name changed to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society, Inc. Memorandum of Agreement transferred management from The Research Ranch Foundation (aka The Research Ranch, Inc.) to National Audubon Society.
events.source: Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Jack Lewis sells most of his interest in La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: Jack Lewis sells most of his interest in La Posta Quemada Ranch to Armond Arnson, head of a Cleveland consortium of investors, and enters into a partnership with them, still hoping to create a resort on the Ranch

events.title: Memorandum of Understanding: Forest Service and National Audubon Society
events.description: MOU signed ''to cooperate in studies to encourage research on factors related to maintaining and improving management of Southwestern desert grasslands and to maintain the established Elgin Research Natural Area.' MOU dated June 14, July 28, & July 13, 1982; Dr. Mark Stromberg is Resident Director of the Research Ranch
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Illegal grading of Rancho del Lago
Arizona State Museum surveys 30 historic sites for Anamax
events.source: Ayres J. The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) ; 1984.

events.title: Excavations at EE:2:30 and Los Ojitos defined Early Agricultural period
events.description: Bruce Huckell, supported by Anamax Mining Co.and University of Arizona, excavated again at EE:2:30 and at Los Ojitos, 500 meters downstream in Cienega Creek channel. Large numbers of artifacts and pithouses represented early agricultural village settlement occupied year round for perhaps a decade. Work provided basis for defining the Cienega phase of Early Agricultural Period as 800 BC to AD50. Huckell notes the diverse biotic communities, first-class farmland along a gentle flowing perennial stream and a relatively long growing season were highly conducive to maize agriculture in the area.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Walter Armer submits first instream flow for Cienega Creek
events.description: Walter Armer (rancher, Flying R/Bar V) submits first instream flow for Cienega Creek; downstream is Horizon Corporation (illegally graded right before '83 flood)

events.title: Flood of 1983 revives continuous flow in areas of Cienega Creek
events.description: Flood recharges Cienega Creek groundwaters and causes cottonwood recruitment; Hannas living on the Reserve couldn't cross the creek for 6 weeks. Flood created areas that flowed for several years after. Based on this observation a development plan for 12,000 units does not need surface water rights

events.title: Due to flood, streamflow monitoring begins and cottonwood saplings are found
events.description: Montgomery Associates begin monitoring streamflow. Hannas (living on the Cienega Creek Reserve) report numerous cottonwood saplings due to scouring; very few cottonwoods before

events.title: Chiricahua Leopard Frogs extirpated from Finley Tank
events.description: On the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch, staff determines that Chiricahua Leopard Frogs extirpated from Finley Tank
events.source: Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Anamax Land Exchange proposal is dropped
events.description: Anamax Mining Co. Land Exchange proposal is dropped with Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Clean Water Act in Arizona
events.description: Act requires consideration and permitting for actions that impact Waters of the US. Corps of Engineer begins to administer Clean Water Act of 1972 in Pima County.
events.source: United States. Clean Water Act as Amended through 1972. PL92-500. 33US Code 1251. Washington, DC: Government Printing Office; 1972

events.title: Food Security Act
events.description: Food Security Act requires all farmers to have a conservation plan on HEL soils and wetlands to participate in USDA programs, including commodities.

events.title: Pima County acquires the Cienega Creek Nature Preserve
events.description: Rancher Walter Armer sells his ranch to Pima County which becomes the Pima County Cienega Creek Nature Preserve. Julia Fonseca begins at Cienega Creek as the first preserve manager
events.source: Fonseca J.. Cienega Watershed Shared History Part Three. Personal Communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Bureau of Land Management and National Audubon Society partner on Appleton Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Cooperative Agreement signed between BLM and National Audubon Society ''for the management of public lands within the Appleton-Whittell Biological Research Sanctuary' (The Research Ranch) August 8, 1986. Arizona State Land Dept. re-conveyed State's County Bond Trust lands and School Trust lands within Section 16 (T21S,R18E) [Research Ranch] to BLM
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Unique waters nomination for Cienega Creek
events.description: Portion of Cienega Creek downstream of I-10, upstream of dam in T16S R16E Sec 14 nominated to provide enhanced water quality protection because of Creek's high water quality and rare ecological and recreational resources.
events.source: Fonseca J et al. Unique Waters Final Nomination Report for Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; Nov 28 1990

events.title: Orange Coast Group, California, proposes 10,000 seat amphitheatre near Colossal Cave Park
events.description: Orange Coast Group CA proposes to build 10,000-seat amphitheatre immediately to southwest of Colossal Cave Park. When made general knowledge in April, public outcry from all over US defeats proposal

events.title: Frank Appleton conveys 800 acres to Appleton Whittell Research Ranch.
events.description: Adding to Audubon's Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, Frank Appleton conveys 800 acres in Sections 27 & 28 (T21S,R18E. Ultimate the lands are conveyed to the Bureau of Land Management through 3rd party exchange.
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Failed effort to acquire Empire Ranch for open space
events.description: Efforts fail for Pima County to acquire Empire Ranch (for open space corridor from Mexico to Oracle; (ranch marketed as “ranchettes”) – conservation biology principles of keeping landscapes whole/intact are having effect at this time

events.title: Fire burns 2,500 upland acres on Research Ranch
events.description: Large fire is caused by lightning, burning 2,500 acres on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch

events.title: ASARCO acquires the Anamax holdings
events.description: ASARCO acquires the Anamax Mining Co. holdings. Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Bureau of Land Management acquires Empire Ranch
events.description: BLM acquires Empire Ranch through a land exchange, administered as Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area. Donaldson's ranching lease and use of headquarters continues.
events.source: Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46
events.source (original): Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: BLM designates Appleton Whittell Area of Critical Environmental Concern
events.description: Bureau of Land Management designates the 3141 acres acquired from the State Trust lands and the Appletons within the Research Ranch as 'Appleton-Whittell Area of Critical Environmental Concern'; BLM Phoenix Resource Management Plan set prescriptions for the Appleton-Whittell Area of Critical Environmental Concern
events.source: Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Gene Knoder serves as Resident Director of the Research Ranch
events.description: Gene Knoder serves as Resident Director of the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: A large flood
Bureau of Land Management acquires Empire, Cienega and Rose Tree Ranches
events.description: Bureau of Land Management continues Donaldson's grazing lease and use of headquarters continues. The area is administered as the Empire-Cienega Conservation Area
events.source: Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Grey Hawks sighted on Empire-Cienega Conservation Area
events.description: Bureau of Land Management employees Karen and Jeff Simms, who live on the Empire-Cienega Conservation Area, sight a grey hawk pair
events.source: Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: The Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area described as grass over knees
events.description: lots of rain and “grass over knees” –

events.title: Acute drought, monitoring initiated
events.description: Because of the acute drought, the Pima Association of governments begin a monitoring program at the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve (GW ESWS)

events.title: US Forest Service acquires Kentucky Camp
events.description: US Forest Service acquires the property as part of a land swap. Site is named 'Kentucky Camp'… a name that is neutral to its former mining and ranching uses.
events.source: Doumas, M. Kentucky Camp Interpretive Plan. Personal communication.May 10, 2013.

events.title: BLM established the Tucson Field Office
events.description: From Safford District, Bureau of Land Management. BLM Officials took down some old buildings on the Empire' 1992-1996 Tucson Area Office Manager Jesse Juen
events.source: Public Lands Foundation. Historical Record of the Offices, Managers and Organizations of the U. S. Bureau of Land Management, Grazing Service, General Land Office and O&C Revested Lands Administration 1934 - 2012. Phoenix, AZ: Public Lands Foundation; April 2012
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Colossal Cave Park combined with La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: Pima County Parklands Foundation takes over 5,714 acres of State grazing leases belonging to La Posta Quemada Ranch. Pima County Board of Supervisors purchases the Ranch, the Park, and additional acreage, combining Colossal Cave Park and La Posta Quemada Ranch to become Colossal Cave Mountain Park, now about 2,400 acres; CCMP is leased to Pima County Parklands Foundation, a charitable agency; Joe and Martie Maierhauser continue as Park operators for the Foundation.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Gardner fire
Native American plant collection on Las Cienegas
events.description: On Las Cienegas NCA (BLM), Native American collection of plants for basketry and medicine still an interest of some families.
events.source: McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: Bullfrog having a negative effect on Chiricahua Leopard Frog
events.description: The Chiricahua leopard frog is a native frog that is protected by the Endangered Species Act. Bullfrogs prey on these frogs, and often extirpate populations.
events.source: Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.
events.tags: Non-Native, Loss of Animal, ESA status

events.title: Jeff Simms surveys fish at Las Cienegas NCA
events.description: Simms surveys: (would often see 100+ fish, surface water was 10+ miles, now 5-7 miles; tree canopy very sparse, by 2010 swamps forming)

events.title: Stream restoration Cienega Creek Agricultural fields
events.description: Drought affected project by preventing riparian plant colonizations (by 2010 part of project area head cutting; Solution likely to change channel sinuosity.

events.title: Wildlife cameras installed to monitor jaguar
events.description: progress in monitoring proof of jaguar range grabs media attention.

events.title: Livestock grazing ends at Cienega Creek Preserve
Leopard frog population crashes in the watershed
events.source: Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Victorian Addition section of Empire Ranch House roof replaced
events.description: Americorps volunteers install cedar shingles on Victorian Addition roof and make other repairs

events.title: Bureau of Land Management acquires Empire, Cienega, and Rose Tree Ranches, administers as Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area
events.description: Commences baseline surveys for vegetation, birds, fish and other habitats

events.title: Kentucky Camp: New wooden shingle roofs to stabilize adobe
events.description: New wooden shingle roofs are installed on all buildings to stabilize adobe from rain damage. Headquarters building wall rebuilt after years of rain run-off had destroyed it at KY Camp
events.source: Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle [Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: First well at Vail, AZ original town site
events.description: The first well between the tracks hits water at 614 feet.

events.title: Livestock removed from Cienega Creek
events.description: Livestock removed from Cienega creek (deer grass and cattail and pools forming, big change for that area)

events.title: Loss of Chiricahua leopard frog on Cienega Creek (chytrid)
events.description: Loss of Chiricahua leopard frog on creek (officially documented around 1998 in county preserve – documented as chytrid fungus – first detection in US))

events.title: Winter flood long duration causes head cuts as riparian vegetation not sufficient to resist 5 days of flood
Colossal Cave Mountain Park listed on National Register of Historic Places as National Historic District
events.description: Nomination submitted by Linda Mayro, County Archaeologist

events.title: Alien Species Prevention and Enforcement Act passed
events.description: Act prohibits transportation of fish, wildlife, and plants that have been prohibited pursuant to the Lacey Act

events.title: Pima County gets in-streamflow certificate for Cienega Creek
Biological Planning Process begins for Empire Cienega Allotment
events.description: Mac and John Donaldson, permit-holders of BLM lands for the Empire-Cienega Allotment, begin biological planning process as part of their grazing management. Working with Grant Drennen and Karen Simms of the BLM staff, this new approach is later expanded into a formal process.
events.source: Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: Appleton Whittell Research Ranch manager Bill Branan
events.description: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch 1994-2006 Dr. Bill Branan hired as Apacheria Program (Research Ranch) Director, Research Ranch Archives 1993-1995? Dr. Michael Morrison serves as Research Director of the Research Ranch, Research Ranch Archives
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Antelope Days held at the Research Ranch
events.description: Antelope Days held at the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, Research Ranch Archives

events.title: ADWR statewide water assessment
events.description: Arizona publishes first Statewide Water Resources Assessment that examines water supply, demand, and management issues for six planning areas.
events.tags: Groundwater, Springs, Surface, Water developments, Water Rights

events.title: Las Cienegas: BLM fenced off Cienega Creek to cattle
events.description: Huge rip ve response to fencing; consequence and fencing includes heavy canopy cover by even age stands of trees. Less light and more leaf filter affects G topminnow community (negative)

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Management Plan
events.description: A Pima County first draft plan. Parks and Recreation Division don't release the document but use it for preserve management for years
events.source: Scalero D. Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. Personal communication.Nov 2012.

events.title: Kentucky Camp: Retaining wall built behind Cabin A
events.description: Retaining wall built behind Cabin A to mitigate hillside pressure damage.

events.title: Drought period; one of the driest on record in SW US
events.source: Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:46

events.title: ASARCO and Coronado National Forest initiate Land Exchange Memorandum
events.description: ASARCO and Coronado National Forest sign a Memorandum of Understanding to initiate Land Exchange.
events.source: Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Friends of Kentucky Camp forms
events.description: 1995 Friends of Kentucky Camp is formed to assist the Forest Service in the rehabilitation and interpretation of Kentucky Camp.
events.source: Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle {Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership forms
events.description: Volunteer collaborative planning organization: initiated with federal, state, and local agencies, organizations and private citizens, the Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership continues meeting for years. Initially started to complete the Resource Management Plan for the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area managed by the Bureau of Land Management. Issues represented: conservation, grazing, recreation, mining, and biological concerns. events.title: Environmental Quality Incentives Program
events.description: The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) provides a steady and major source of annual support since 1997. In 1997, NRCS is authorized to provide $2 million throughout Arizona through EQIP and it is gradually increased to $10 million in 2002 and reaches $20 million in 2006. A total of 177.5 million dollars is invested from 1997 through 2012. Most of the EQIP money is spent for water development, drought funding, and planning, implement of conservation practices. It has helped to maintain and improve rangeland conditions, especially to alleviate the drought damage brought by the continued warming and drying climate starting the late 1990s.

events.title: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan
events.description: In 1998 Pima County began an extended debate (first political and then scientific) about how to protect natural resources and endangered species from growth, development, and loss of habitat. In 2004 voters approved a bond of $164 M to purchase and protect important parcels of land. In 2016 the Pima County Board of Supervisors gave final approval to the Plan. The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan (SDCP) guides regional efforts to conserve the best lands and most precious resources for future generations of Pima County residents to enjoy. The Plan combines short-term actions with long-range land-use decisions in Pima County, one of the most biologically diverse counties in the U.S. From cactus-studded deserts to conifer forests, the diverse landscape of Pima County is the home to a million residents from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and contains a rich diversity of plant and animal life.

events.title: Colossal Cave Mountain Park Expansion
events.description: Pima County’s first efforts to conserve Colossal Cave began in 1944, when the County leased almost 500 acres from the State Land Department for purposes of a park. Using 1986 voter-approved bond funds for park land acquisition, the County began to establish the mountain park to protect the cave in 1989 and a Pima County park was formally established in 1992. Acquisitions included the historic Posta Quemada Ranch, which is also the site of a 120-year old stagecoach station. Colossal Cave Mountain Park (CCMP) supports habitat for almost half of the bat species in the State of Arizona, including the endangered Lesser Long-nosed bat. CCMP also protects large segments of lush riparian vegetation along Agua Verde Creek, a major tributary to Cienega Creek.

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Expansion
events.description: Recognizing the incredible importance of Cienega Creek and its watershed, the Pima County Board of Supervisors establishes the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve in 1986 using voter-approved bond funds for flood-prone land. Spanning 4,000 acres, the Preserve protects 12 miles of the lower reaches of Cienega Creek, which supports native endangered fish species, provides aquifer recharge, and provides important natural flood control protections that lessen impacts to the developed areas in the Tucson Basin. The Preserve also hosts the historic railroad town of Pantano, along with many archaeological features, including bedrock mortars.

events.title: Bar V Ranch acquisition by Pima County
events.description: 170 acres of private land and 12,000 state trust leased lands are acquired by Pima County with Conservation Bond funding. The property is bounded on the north by the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve and includes the lower watershed of the Davidson Canyon. The property adds to wildlife corridors in the 'Missing Link' and the Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan and protects water resources for numerous endangered species.

events.title: The acquisition of Bar V Ranch
events.description: Pima County’s acquisition of the Bar V Ranch contributes to the conservation of one of the most important wildlife movement corridors in the Cienega Valley. The 14,400 acre Bar V Ranch is located between the Rincon and Santa Rita Mountains, and adjacent to the County’s Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. The ranch includes a significant portion of Davidson Canyon, an important tributary and water source to Cienega Creek and the Tucson Basin. Acquisition of the Bar V Ranch preserves a large intact piece of the Empire-Cienega landscape and protects important riparian habitat crucial for several vulnerable species.

events.title: The acquisition of Clyne and Sands Ranches
events.description: In its entirety, the historic Sands Ranch totals 64,000 acres, spanning east of Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to the San Pedro River in Cochise County. With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County acquires the 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch located in the far southeast corner of Pima County. This acquisition further connects a system of publicly-owned lands from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains, especially when coupled with the County’s subsequent acquisition of the adjacent Clyne Ranch. Not only does it contribute to the health of the Cienega Watershed, but also conserves high quality native grasslands and wildlife movement corridors.

events.title: Melendrez fire
The acquisition of Empirita Ranch
events.description: The Empirita (little Empire) Ranch actually breaks off from the larger Empire Ranch in 1941. In 1991 and 92, the Pima County Flood Control District purchases 360 acres of the Empirita Ranch. In 2001, Pima County’s acquisition of the 2,700-acre Empirita property conserves the last remaining portions of the private land that comprised the historic Empirita Ranch. With assistance from the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County negotiates the purchase of the Empirita property; additionally, the owner assigns the County its contractual right to withdraw up to 1,600 acre feet of groundwater annually from the Cienega Creek Basin. The Empirita acquisition expands upon already conserved reserves, including the Coronado National Forest, the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, and the County’s Bar V Ranch, Empirita Ranch, and Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.

events.title: The acquisition of Clyne Ranch
events.description: The County’s acquisition of 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch, located east of Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, in December 2008, creates an interconnected corridor of conserved lands spanning from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains. With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County then acquires the Clyne Ranch parcels, located adjacent to the County’s Sands Ranch and also east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, totaling 880 acres. In addition, development restrictions are placed on 90 acres maintained by the seller. The ranch is an integral part of this assemblage of publicly-owned lands and further contributes to this corridor through the Cienega Valley. The Clyne Ranch parcels, like the Sands Ranch, contain high quality native grasslands found in the Sonoita Valley area.

events.description: Central Arizona Project water confirmed in groundwater reclamation wells. Isotopic analysis of groundwater withdrawn from CAVSARP, SAVSARP, and Pima Mine Road recharge facilities. Not all wells sampled near the facilities show the presence of CAP water, indicating the influence of subsurface hydrology on CAP water distribution in aquifers.

events.title: Paleo-Indian hunters hunt big game in Southern Arizona
events.description: Humans follow big game (megafauna, mammoth, bison, antelope), smaller animals and gathering plants. No Paleo-Indian sites recorded yet but finding these sites may be difficult due to: 1) sites may be deeply buried and occasionally exposed by erosion into old deposits; 2) the material remains are scant and do not include ceramics, house structures, or other features; 3) due to the mobile patterns; 4) material culture was perishable; and 5) sites are ephemeral in nature and the overall site density would have been low given the hunting and gathering patterns. Site potential exist, known mammoth finds.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: A Great Rift Valley forms in southeastern Arizona
events.description: The rift valley is associated with the formation of the Gulf of Mexico. Ocean waters fill the southeastern portion of the valley, ebbing and flowing through the years. Rift valley lakes fill the northwestern portions of the valley, as far north as Tucson. A particularly large lake, perhaps 20 miles wide and 60 miles long exists for a period in this area.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Area covered (mostly) by a shallow sea

events.title: Massive volcanic activity from a giant volcano may have ended local life
events.description: Massive volcanic activity from giant volcanos in the area, at a scale that one must suspect largely eliminated life. Upon emptying out its magma chamber, one of the volcanos collapses in on itself forming a giant caldera in the Mt Fagan area.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rocks of the Fort Crittenden Formation deposited
events.description: Deposited in intermontane lakes and alluvial fans form during early laramide deformation. Fossils include: petrified wood, pollen, snails, mussels, fishes (Lepisosteus, Melvius, Pachyrhizodus, Palaeolabrus), turtles (Adocus, Plastomenus, Helopanoplia, Trionyx sl), a polyglyphonodontine lizard, an alligatoroid and dinosaurs (Tyrannosaur, Allosauroid, Dromaeosaurid, Hadrosaurine, Nasutoceratops (?), Chasmosaur, Ankylosaurine, and Egg Shell).
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Wildfires are frequent in this area

events.description: The Archaic prehistory period is marked by patterns of hunting and intensive plant collecting with seasonal mobile camps for thousands of years. Many sites exist in the Cienega Valley attesting to this successful adaptation to changing environments.
events.source: Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: George Crook commands Army forces in AZ Territory
events.description: In 1872 Colonel George Crook defeats Northern Apaches, who agree to reside on reservation. O.O. Howard persuades Cochise to inhabit Chiricahua reservation in Sulphur Springs Valley. By end of 1872 southern Arizona Territory is relatively peaceful and continues so until 1875 when Crook is reassigned to the Northern Plains to subdue the Sioux Indians. This era of peace defines the arrival of many ranchers, the onset of the cattle industry, and the rush for previously unused grasslands.
events.source: Sweeney E. From Cochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886.. Norman OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2010

events.title: George Crook returns to Arizona Territory to round up last of Chiricahua Apache
events.description: Brigadier General Crook returns to Arizona after Chiricahua Indian Reservation has been abolished, Apaches sent to San Carlos Indian Reservation. Bad conditions and unfair treatment cause many to flee. Geronimo and Naiche and small remaining band are last to agree return to reservation. Failure to arrange their return forces Crook to request a transfer from Arizona Territory.
events.source: Sweeney E. From Cochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886.. Norman OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2010

events.title: Nelson Miles commands AZ military to capture last of Chiricahua Apache
events.description: General Nelson A. Miles assumes command of all Southwest Army forces to recapture last of Chiricahua Apaches. Indians brought to Fort Bowie and deported from Arizona to Florida on September 8 1886.
events.source: Sweeney E. From Cochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886.. Norman OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2010

events.title: Theodore White surveys 7 townships around Cienega Valley
events.description: Surveyor Theodore White is contracted by the General Land Office in Tucson to survey seven 6-mile by 6-mile townships in the Cienega valley. White records descriptions of natural resources, landmarks, human habitations, roads, and locations and distances between. Using descriptions and precise measurements, he draws first detailed map of each township. These maps are published in the General Land Office and used later by homesteaders and miners to make individual claims. No claims can be filed until a formal survey has been made. With these surveys of the watershed, settlement of the valley by ranchers and farmers accelerates.
events.source: Gillespie W. . Personal Communication.April 18, 2017.

events.title: Sanford Family Land Acquisition in Cienega Valley
events.description: Don Alonzo Sanford settles at the confluence of Wood, Stevenson, and Cienega Creeks in 1874 in Township 18 South Range 17 East, Section 23. Sanford’s brother, Franklin, claims land two miles south in the area now known as the “Ag Fields.” Sanford brings his fiancé, Louisa Bloxton, and her brothers, John and Robert, to join his Cienega settlement later in the same year. All homestead or purchase lands along the Creek and claim water rights. Their claims provide the family with some of the richest grazing and tillable lands within Cienega Valley. Their family control of land and water in the middle Cienega Valley area essentially excludes any competing ranching enterprise.

events.title: Don Alonzo Sanford 's diversified endeavors in Cienega Valley
events.description: Sanford invests in land, mining claims, built properties in Tucson, and livestock. He provides substantial quantities of beef and barley to nearby Forts Huachuca and Lowell and to the San Carlos Indian reservation. By 1880 Sanford is running 1,000 head of cattle and 23,000 sheep on lands that he controls between the Empire and the Whetstone Mountains as far north as the Pantano Valley. Sanford raises feed crops in the floodplain of the Cienega Creek and maintains an extensive orchard of fruit trees. Sanford apparently waters these agricultural lands from an irrigation system of his own construction. Sanford sells his Meadows Valley Ranch (also called the Stock Valley Ranch) to Walter Vail in November 1882.

events.title: Agriculture and Water Distribution at Empire Ranch
events.description: At the Sanford Ranch, the Vails use the extensive floodplain for agricultural production; they plow a number of individual fields, each of which probably supports different crops. In 1892 Walter Vail expands agricultural endeavors to the riparian area near the Empire Ranch. Vail files a Desert Land claim on bottom lands 1/2 mile east of the corrals and around Empire Gulch. He conveys water during spring and summer months in a ¾ mile long ditch with numerous laterals to a broad flat area on the northeast and southwest sides of the Gulch. That irrigation system supports 250 fruit trees and five tons of corn, barley, and alfalfa annually. It also provides stock waters for the horse and newly-weaned calf herds.

events.title: Forest fire raging on Rincon Mountains
events.description: This fire damages timber in the Rincon Mountains, some of the most heavily timbered mountains in Pima County. According to Vail's Station store owner Otto Schley, it has been burning since June 22, 1907. The government is contemplating creating a forest reserve. There are from time to time small sawmills in the Rincon Mountains.

events.title: Frank Schmidt dies at age 85
events.description: He has been at Colossal Cave Park for 35 years, having explored it, protected it, and developed it
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Joe Maierhauser dies at age 79
events.description: He has been at Colossal Cave Mountain Park for 50 years. HIs wife, Martie, continues as Park Director and Operator
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Byron Cummings takes two expeditions into Colossal Cave
events.description: Professor of Archaeology Byron Cummings, Director of the Arizona State Museum, later President of the University of Arizona, takes two expeditions into the Cave. He makes a survey and a map, naming the formations and passageways. He finds a number of Indian artifacts, as well as two human skeletons.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Frank J. 'Pop' Schmidt arrives in Tucson
events.description: Frank J. 'Pop' Schmidt, a native of Cologne, Germany, arrives in Tucson
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Edward Nye Fish at Cienega Valley and Empire Ranch
events.description: Edward Nye Fish invests in a variety of industries including cattle ranching, horse breeding, mining, freighting and trading. Fish recognizes the value of the natural resources available in the Cienega Valley. In the late 1860s, Fish and neighbor, Thomas Gardner, cut lumber at their sawmill on the nearby slopes of the Santa Rita Mountains to sell in Tucson. By 1871, Fish has purchased, and is probably living in, the original four-room adobe core of the Empire Ranch’s main house. The original builder of the Main Ranch House is not known.

events.title: Frank Schmidt files two mining claims on land occupied by Colossal Cave
events.description: Frank Schmidt files two mining claims on land occupied by the Cave, and sublets land surrounding it from Empire Ranch. He and three others are reported by local newspapers to have made the first extensive survey of the Cave, traveling within it for six days before exhausting their supply of food and water.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: High quality grazing resources noted in Cienega Valley
events.description: “[the ranch is] in the middle of a splendid grazing country which is covered with grass the whole season. Mr. Fish’s title only covers 160 acres, but as he has all the water in his section of the country there is little danger of anyone settling there. The nearest water that lasts through the dry season is at least eight miles off, and every way you go for a radius of 15 miles is covered with fine bunch grass which will keep either horses or cattle rowling (sic) fat both winter and summer… I think it is as fine a cattle country as there is anywhere in the world ….” Walter Vail.

events.title: Hay harvested from the Cienega floodplain
events.description: As early as 1874, hay is harvested in the Cienega floodplain for winter feed for livestock. The Vails also harvest hay on the Gardner and Sanford ranches. In the 1890s the Vails hire Mormon families from St. David to cut sacaton grass from the floodplain. Hay is stored in the Adobe Haybarn South of the Ranch House.

events.title: Vail family land and water acquisitions
events.description: Using new funds from his partner and uncle, Nathan Vail, Walter Vail purchases Tom Gardner’s Apache Spring Ranch 7 miles Southwest of the Empire Ranch in March, 1881, for its abundant water. To consolidate control of other water sources in Cienega, Walter Vail also files numerous mill and mining claims on springs and seeps in the Empire and Santa Rita mountains. Walter Vail purchases a small parcel of land in Section 28, T19S R17E, known as 'Cottonwood' in 1893, which sits at the well-used intersection where the road to Fort Huachuca passes across Gardner Canyon. Cottonwood still operates as an important water source. A well and reservoir provide water to two recently divided ponds that separately supply cattle and wildlife.

events.title: Water transported to Empire Ranch orchard
events.description: Vail's ditch-transport system to carry Gulch water is short-lived and soon replaced with more efficient plumbing. In the 1930s, water for the Empire Ranch Orchard is transported from Empire Gulch through a six-inch pipe down to a livestock trough west of the cottonwood grove lining the Gulch. The water fills a 50’ long, double-sided concrete trough and its overflow then continues to a reservoir below or on down to fields.

events.title: Bartlett's boundary survey documents conditions along proposed US-Mexico border
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico, Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua. Includes observations of flora, fauna, people, geography. Chapter 17 covers area that includes Cienega Watershed.
events.source: Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854

events.title: Franklin Delano Roosevelt creates Civilian Conservation Corps
events.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) is established by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt during the Great Depression of the 1930s. The purpose of the Corps is twofold: to provide jobs for unemployed young men, and to preserve and develop the nation’s natural resources by assisting the Departments of Agriculture and Interior with forest, park, and soil conservation projects. “CCC boys” as they are called, are unmarried men between the ages of 17 and 24. In general, they earn $30.00 per month, of which $25.00 goes home to their families. The CCC camps are overseen by U.S. Army personnel, while the work is supervised by other agencies.
events.source:
Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000:
Hunt SE, Lamb JJ, Maierhauser M. Civilian Conservation Corps Scrapbook: Camp SP-10-A Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Tucson, AZ: Colossal Cave Mountain Park; 2012

events.title: Solomon Lick's daughter dies of burns
events.description: Solomon Lick's baby daughter overturns a candle or lamp at the Mountain Springs Hotel, and dies of her burns
events.source:
Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000:
Hunt SE, Lamb JJ, Maierhauser M. Civilian Conservation Corps Scrapbook: Camp SP-10-A Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Tucson, AZ: Colossal Cave Mountain Park; 2012

events.title: First formal exploration of Colossal Cave
events.description: January 23, 1879: a party leaves Tucson for Mountain Springs, eager to explore 'the cave or tunnel near there'. January 26, 1879: the Arizona Daily Star reports on the five-hour expedition into what it calls the 'Arizona Catacombs,' in which the exploring party finds 'a thousand varied beauties'.
events.source: Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership adds directors and officers
events.description: Officers approved: Shela McFarlin, Chairman; Tahnee Robertson, Vice-Chairman; Larry Fisher, Secretary; new board members Robert Fink, Bob Hernbrode and Frank Postillion joined Mead Mier, Thomas Meixner, Chris In-Albon as board members.

events.title: Jose Maria Romero Homestead Patent
events.description: Jose Maria Romero proves up on the southwest quarter of th southwest quarter of Section twenty-six, the south half of the southeast quarter and the south half of the southwest quarter of Section twenty-seven, and the southeast quarter of the southeast quarter of Section twenty-eight in Township fifteen south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona, containing two hundred forty acres. Patent Number 1043206
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Santiago Leon Homestead Patent
events.description: Santiago Leon proves up on the southwest quarter of section thirty three in Township fifteen south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona, containing one hundred sixty acres. Patent Number 282047
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Jose Maria Romero Homestead Patent
events.description: Jose Maria Romero proves up on the west half of the southwest quarter of Section twenty-eight and the west half of the northwest quarter of Section thirty-three in Township fifteen south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona, containing one hundred sixty acres. One hundred and sixty acres. 607407
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Santiago Leon Homestead Patent
events.description: The heirs of Santiago Leon claim lot two of Section four in Township sixteen south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona, containing twenty acres and seven hundredths of an acre. Patent Number 1067182
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Teclo Lujan Homestead Patent
events.description: Teclo Lujan proves up on 160 acres. The southeast quarter of Section 14 in Township sixteen south and Range sixteen east.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Victor Chavez Homestead Patent
John B Fraker Homestead Patent
events.description: John B. Fraker claims 160 acres in Township 16 south, Range 16 east in th South half of the southeast quarter of Section 4 and in Township 16 south, Range 16 east in the east one half of the northeast quarter of Section 9. John B Fraker, along with Carter Crane, developed a large farming operation watered by waters channeled from Cienega Creek

events.description: Winifred W. Lorentson, widow of Carl E. Lorentson files homestead claim for 640 acres located in the east half and the east half of the southwest quarter of Section eleven and the northeast quarter and the east half of the northwest quarter of Section fourtheen in Township 16 south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Carter D Crane Homestead Patent near Vail
events.description: Carter D Crane claims a 280 acre homestead entry in the north half of the southeast quarter, the north half of the southwest quarter of the northwest quarter and the east half of the northwest quarter of Section fifteen in Township sixteen south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizn Carter Crane, along with John B Fraker, developed a large farming operation watered by waters channeled from Cienega Creek.

events.title: Abram Bravo Homestead Patent near Vail
events.description: Abram Bravo claims 160 acres in Township 13 south, Range 13 east in the southeast quarter of Section 21.

events.title: Edward Nye Fish Homestead Patent
events.description: Edward Nye Fish claims 640 acres in Township 13 south, Ranch 13 east in the west one half of the southwest quarter of Section 17, and in Township 13 south Range 13 east southeast quarter of southwest quarter of Section 17. And, Township 13 south, Range 13 east, southeast quarter of northeast quarter of Section 18, Township 13 south, Range 13 east, northeat quarter of southeast quarter of Section 18, and Township 13 south, Range 13 east in the western one half of northeast quarter of Section 20.

events.title: Sylvester D. Bell Homestead Patent
events.description: Sylvester D. Bell cash entry. Northeast quarter of the northeast quarter of Section twenty and the northwest quarter of the northwest quarter of Section twenty-one in Township 13 south o Range 13 east of the Gila and Salt River meridian, Arizona, containing eighty acres.

events.title: Andrada Ranch Estates subdivision established
events.description: Andrada Ranch Estates, New Tucson Unit No 22 established as a subdivision of improved lots

events.title: Santa Fe Pacific Railroad land claim
events.description: The Santa Fe Pacific Railroad Company is granted reconveyed lands under the April 1904 Act in Section thirty-four in Township sixteen south and Sections three, four, nine, and ten in Township seenteen south all in Ranch sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian containing three thousand thirty-nine acres . Patent 720542

events.title: Casimiro Bravo Homestead Patent
events.description: Casimiro Bravo proves up on his homestead land claim containing two hundred eighty acres located in the north half of the southeast quarter, the north half of the southwest quarter, the southwest quarter of the northwest quarter and the east half of the northwest quarter of Section 15 in Township 16 south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Marie M. Contzen Homestead Patent
events.description: Marie M. Contzen files homestead/ stock raising claim for 640 acres. Township 14 south, Range 14 East, northwest northeast of Section 3. Township 16 south, Range 16 east, southeast Section 3, east one half of southwest of Section 3, east one half of northwest Section 10, northeast of Section 10, north one half of southeast Section 10, southeast, southeast of Section 10.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Frederick J W Contzen Homestead Patent
events.description: Frederick J W Contzen files homestead/stock raising claim for 160 acres. Township 11 south Range 14 east, northeast corner of southeast corner of Section 26, and northeast corner of northeast corner of Section 34 in Township 14 south, Range 14, and wester one half of southwest corner of Sectin three in Township 16 south, Range 16 east. And, a homestead/stock raising entry for 640 acres in northeast corner of northeast corner of Section 34, Township 14 south, Range 14 east, northeast corner of southeast corner of Section 26, Township 11 south, Range 14 east, south one half of Section 27 in Township 14 south, Range 11 east, and the north one half of the north one half corner of Section 34 in Township 14 south, Section 11 east, and, the western one half of the southwest corner of Section 3 in Township 16 south and Range 16 east.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Charles C. Day land claim near Vail
events.description: Rancher Charles C. Day files an Exchange-Pvt w/Navajo land claim for 160 acres in the northeast of Section 26 in Township 16 south, Range 16 east.

events.title: Tucson - Vail - Tucson Motorcycle Race
events.description: This is the only July 4th event scheduled in 1915 for Tucson and Vail. The race begins at the Tucson Carnegie Library heads east to Vail. There is a 30-minute rest stop at Schley's Store (1908 Old Vail Post Office) before the race resumes to end at the Tucson Carnegie Library. Lorenzo Boido’s Indian motorcycle crosses the finish line at the Carnegie Library with a time of 49:34. D.J. Buck is 2nd with a time of 51:30, Ray Reynolds on his Excelsior makes the 44 mile course in 57:01, and Highfill, the local dark horse, finishes 6th with a respectable time of 66:45 on his Flying Merkle.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Benito Dominguez Homestead Patent near Vail
events.description: Benito Dominguez files a cash entry for 160 acres located in the western one half of the southeast corner of Section 24, Township 16 south, Range 16 east, and the northeast corner of the southwest corner of Section 24, Township 16 south, Range 16 east, and the southeast corner of the southeast corner of Section 24, Township 16 east, Range 16 east.
events.source: Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Turkeys appear in Colossal Cave Mountain Park
events.description: A tom and several hens roam an area extending from the North Picnic Areas to La Posta Quemada Ranch.There is speculation that they were driven down from the higher Rincons by drought and fires; they are still seen occasionally.
events.source: Maierhauser M, Show S. Turkeys in Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Personal observation, Personal communication.August, 2011.

events.title: Floodwaters, 60-80 feet deep cause railroad track washout on Cienega Creek
events.description: The Arizona Weekly Citizen reports floodwaters 60-80 feet deep rushed though Cienega Creek in places where the creek is 200 feet wide. One of the rails is taken out and and the telegraph service is disrupted. 'The track was not all washed away through the Cienega. The bridges, culverts and their approaches suffered the most.' Cribbing is being used temporarily while repairs are made.

events.title: Arizona Wilderness Act of 1984
events.description: The AZ Wilderness Act approves the additions of many portions of USFS lands within Arizona to the National Wilderness Preservation System including parts of the Coronado National Forest

events.title: Morrill Act
events.description: The Morrill Act of 1862 is signed by President Lincoln to establish Land Grant Colleges mostly in western states to support education in agriculture and engineering. Thomas Jefferson had recognized and pushed for public institutions that would bring practical knowledge to the people and use science to address immediate issues and problems.

events.title: Smith-Lever Act of 1914
events.description: The purpose of the Smith-Lever Act is to create the Cooperative Extension System to further spread knowledge of agriculture, economics, leadership, and home economics into each state and county. State and Federal funds are directed to apply modern science to the specific needs of the communities. The land grant colleges provide the practical information that would be disseminated by farm and ranch advisers through non-formal educational programs.
